questions.text:
An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from her nursing home because of increasing confusion and lethargy for 12 hours. The nursing home aide says she did not want to get out of bed this morning and seemed less responsive than usual. She has Alzheimer disease, hypertension, and a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis for which she underwent percutaneous nephrolithotomy repeatedly. She has chronic, intractable urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. Current medications include galantamine, memantine, and ramipril. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation of the lower abdomen. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9000/mm3



Platelet count
355,000/mm3



Urine



 pH


8.5 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


 Glucose
1+


 Protein
2+


 Ketones
negative


 RBC
5/hpf


 WBC

35/hpf


 Bacteria

moderate


 Nitrites

positive


Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of UTI overall, as well as the most common cause of catheter-associated UTI. While urinalysis in UTI due to E. coli typically shows positive nitrite, E. coli does not cause alkaline urine. In addition, it is not commonly associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with a UTI, alkaline urine (pH > 8), and an indwelling urinary catheter are most likely infected with Proteus mirabilis. P. mirabilis converts urea in the urine into ammonia, which has an alkalizing effect and can cause magnesium ammonium phosphate stones (i.e., struvite kidney stones), which typically require interventional stone removal. The incidence of P. mirabilis increases with the duration of catheterization; it is rare in short-term catheterization but has been found in ∼ 40% of chronically catheterized patients. In this case, empiric antibiotic treatment with parenteral ceftriaxone or ciprofloxacin, urine culture and sensitivity testing, replacement of the urinary catheter (due to risk of colonization and biofilm formation), and (if confirmed) stone removal are the most appropriate next steps in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor recurrent nephrolithiasis. Furthermore, because enterococci are unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in case of enterococcal UTI.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI, especially because of its ability to form biofilms that are resistant to antibiotic therapy. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor does it commonly lead to recurrent nephrolithiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common cause of UTI in young, sexually active women. It is rare in older and/or catheterized patients. Although S. saprophyticus produces urease and thereby alkalinizes urine, it is unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite. Therefore, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in cases of staphylococcal UTI.

F) INCORRECT:

Enterobacter cloacae can cause UTI, particularly in women. It is rare in catheterized patients, does not produce an alkaline urine pH, and is not associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory studies are highly suggestive of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The organism most likely responsible produces urease, which can convert urea into ammonia and lend urine a characteristic scent.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe right-sided flank pain for 3 hours. The pain is colicky, radiates toward his right groin, and he describes it as 8/10 in intensity. He has vomited once. He has no history of similar episodes in the past. Last year, he was treated with naproxen for swelling and pain of his right toe. He has a history of hypertension. He drinks one to two beers on the weekends. Current medications include amlodipine. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen and right costovertebral angle tenderness. An upright x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 7-mm stone in the proximal ureter and grade I hydronephrosis of the right kidney. Results of urinalysis are most likely to show which of the following in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monohydrate calcium oxalate stones have a dumbbell-shaped appearance. Calcium-containing stones are the most common type of urinary stone but are radiopaque and typically visible on a plain x-ray. Uric acid stones typically have a rhomboid or rosette shape.

B) INCORRECT:

Positive leukocyte esterase on urinalysis indicates significant pyuria, which is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). While vomiting, tachycardia, and costovertebral angle tenderness are concerning for pyelonephritis in this patient, he does not have fever, chills, dysuria, or urgency. UTIs are typically associated with alkaline urine and may lead to radiopaque struvite stones and staghorn calculi.

C) CORRECT:

Low urinary pH (i.e., acidic urine) promotes the formation of uric acid and cystine stones. Because organic acids are less soluble when protonated, they tend to form crystals in an acidic environment. Uric acid stones are radiolucent and cannot be detected on plain x-ray. These stones commonly develop in individuals with persistent uricosuria as a result of a protein- or purine-rich diet or increased uric acid production (e.g., in states of increased cell turnover). Urinary uric acid crystals can have a variety of shapes but most commonly appear as rhomboid or rosette crystals.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

D) INCORRECT:

Kidney and ureteral stones commonly manifest with hematuria secondary to epithelial irritation or injury, but the red blood cells do not form RBC casts. RBC casts indicate a glomerular origin of RBCs, suggesting glomerulonephritis, glomerular ischemia, or malignant hypertension, none of which are typically associated with urolithiasis. In this patient, red blood cells on urinalysis would have been expected, but no RBC casts.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive urine sodium nitroprusside test is pathognomic for cystinuria. Cystine stones might not be easily visible on a plain x-ray as they are only weakly radiopaque. However, cystinuria usually causes recurrent stones from childhood, unlike this patient's first presentation during adulthood. A history that suggests gout also makes a different type of stone more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's likely history of acute gout (toe pain and swelling) and a radiolucent stone (not visible on plain x-ray but visible on a CT scan) suggest a uric acid stone.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe right flank pain for 2 hours. The pain is colicky in nature and she describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. She has had 2 episodes of vomiting. She has no history of similar episodes in the past. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 104 kg (229 lb); BMI is 41 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 116/76 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant. Bowel sounds are reduced. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 7400/mm3. A low-dose CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a round 14-mm stone in the distal right ureter. Urine dipstick is mildly positive for blood. Microscopic examination of the urine shows RBCs and no WBCs. Intravenous 0.9% saline infusion is begun, and intravenous ketorolac is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Interventional management with stone removal is the most appropriate step in management for patients with large urinary stones (> 10 mm). For patients with ureteral stones, ureterorenoscopy (URS) and extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) are the preferred treatment modalities. Generally, URS is preferred over ESWL for the removal of stones in the middle and distal ureter. After removal, the composition of the stone is analyzed so that specific guidance on lifestyle and/or diet can be provided. The most important measure to prevent urinary stones in any patient is adequate fluid intake to decrease the risk of crystallization.

B) INCORRECT:

Prior to the invention of endoscopy, ureterolithotomy used to be the standard treatment for complex ureteral stones that did not pass spontaneously or in patients who developed sepsis. Today, however, surgical stone removal, including robotic-assisted or traditional laparoscopic removal is only considered in rare cases in which interventional methods (i.e., shock wave lithotripsy, endoscopic stone removal) have failed, or are likely to fail in the future (e.g., because of large, complex stones). This patient has a simple round stone and no clinical signs of sepsis (e.g., fever, hypotension, tachypnea).

C) INCORRECT:

A trial of conservative management consisting of medical expulsive therapy (e.g., tamsulosin) and analgesia under observation is indicated for patients with small (≤ 10 mm), uncomplicated stones. Because larger stones are unlikely to pass spontaneously, another step in management is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Ureteral stenting is recommended in patients with ureteral stones who develop complications such as (infected) hydronephrosis or sepsis. This patient does not have fever, leukocytosis, or an elevated WBCs on urine microscopy, which would suggest a urinary tract infection. Furthermore, ureteral stenting is not routinely recommended prior to any ureteral intervention.
questions.hint: Severe unilateral colicky flank pain, vomiting, costovertebral angle tenderness, and hematuria suggest urolithiasis. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirms an uncomplicated large stone in the distal right ureter.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe left flank pain and nausea for 3 hours. The pain is colicky and radiates toward his left groin. He drinks multiple glasses of iced tea every day. He has had similar episodes of abdominal pain in the past. His maternal uncle has a similar history of abdominal pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 108/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present. An x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. A urinary cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rhomboid crystals on urinalysis are seen in cases of uric acid stones. Although these stones are classically radiolucent on x-ray, their development is strongly associated with increased serum uric acid levels. This otherwise healthy young adult has no risk factors for increased uric acid levels, such as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a history of gout, or tumor lysis syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

A urinary pH of 7.8 indicates alkaline urine. Alkaline urine promotes the formation of calcium phosphate stones and struvite stones. While these stones can also manifest with episodic, colicky abdominal pain, they are both radiopaque and would thus appear on x-ray. Moreover, this young, otherwise healthy patient does not have significant risk factors for the development of alkaline urine, such as diuretic use or a urinary tract infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies are often present in certain diseases causing bowel inflammation, particularly Crohn disease, which increases the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation. Apart from abdominal pain with costovertebral tenderness, this patient has no history of other inflammatory bowel disease symptoms (e.g., diarrhea or malabsorption). Additionally, calcium oxalate stones are an unlikely cause of urolithiasis in this patient because they would not cause a positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH levels can cause hypercalciuria, which predisposes to calcium stone formation. Calcium stones are virtually always radiopaque, whereas this patient has a stone that is not visualized on x-ray. Furthermore, this young patient has no risk factors for parathyroid disease, such as previous neck radiation or lithium use.

E) INCORRECT:

Proteus mirabilis is a common cause of community-acquired urinary tract infection and struvite stones. Struvite stones arise due to the presence of ammonia in the urine, which is often due to the urease activity of P. mirabilis. Struvite stones also manifest with colicky abdominal pain. However, these stones are radiopaque on abdominal x-ray. Moreover, a urine cyanide nitroprusside test would be negative.

F) CORRECT:

Hexagonal crystals on urinalysis indicate cystine stones, which typically develop in individuals with cystinuria and persistently acidic urine. Cystinuria is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in the cystine-reabsorbing proximal convoluted tubule transporter in the kidneys. Cystine stones are weakly radiopaque (i.e., visible on CT scan but not necessarily on x-ray). A positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test confirms the diagnosis. Prevention includes adequate hydration, a low-sodium diet, urine alkalinization, and, in refractory cases, tiopronin and chelating agents (e.g., penicillamine).

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cystine crystals from a canine urine sample (1000x magnification)

A clump of multiple, clear, hexagon-shaped crystals is visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of cystine crystals.
questions.hint: Colicky flank pain radiating to the groin with costovertebral angle tenderness is suggestive of urolithiasis. Recurrent urolithiasis in an adolescent with negative x-ray findings raises suspicion for cystinuria.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of severe right-sided back pain for the last hour. The pain is colicky and radiates to the right groin. The patient also reports nausea and pain with urination. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side. Urine studies show:


Protein
negative


RBC casts
negative


RBC
5–7/hpf


WBC casts
negative


WBC
1–2/hpf


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lower urinary tract infection (e.g., cystitis) is very common in pregnant patients since the enlarging uterus increases urinary stasis and progesterone diminishes the effectiveness of bladder mobility. Infections generally present with low-grade or no fever, dysuria, and suprapubic tenderness. Urinalysis shows hematuria, positive leukocyte esterase, and pyuria. In this patient, the absence of true pyuria (> 10 WBC) and the presence of colicky flank pain are inconsistent with the common presentation of a lower urinary tract infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion is a surgical emergency seen most often in nonpregnant and first-trimester women as the gravid uterus limits the mobility of the ovaries in women further along in pregnancy. Affected patients often describe acute progressive, unilateral, lower quadrant pain after exercise or other physical activity. This patient is already in the 30th week of pregnancy. Moreover, ovarian torsion could not explain the microscopic hematuria or costovertebral tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

Cholecystitis is common in pregnancy due to decreased gallbladder motility and increased cholesterol content of bile. The typical presentation of cholecystitis is episodic right upper quadrant pain (with possible radiation to the back or right shoulder), especially after meals, along with nausea and vomiting. The patient described here has unilateral pain but it radiates to the groin and there is no report of symptoms being temporally related to eating. Additionally, cholecystitis would not explain her dysuria and hematuria.

D) CORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis typically manifests with unilateral, colicky flank pain that may radiate to the groin with associated costovertebral angle tenderness and is usually associated with microscopic hematuria and dysuria. To confirm the diagnosis, imaging is required. The gold standard would be a nonenhanced abdominopelvic CT scan to calculate size, site, and density of the stone and detect possible hydronephrosis on the affected side. However, since this patient is pregnant, the modality of choice would be ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and the bladder, which can also rule out other gynecological differential diagnoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is usually caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis. It may also manifest with dysuria and nausea; however, abnormal vaginal discharge would be expected as well as severe pain of the lower abdomen instead of back pain. There is also no sexual history to indicate that this patient is at increased risk of PID. Furthermore, the risk of PID is generally lower in pregnancy since the cervical mucus plug prevents bacteria from ascending. Lastly, PID would not typically cause hematuria.

F) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis is a significant cause of maternal and fetal morbidity. The typical presentation consists of high fevers (> 39.0° C), chills, and constant unilateral flank pain with dysuria as well as urinary frequency and urgency. Urinalysis almost always exhibits hematuria and pyuria. Although this patient has flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and hematuria, she does not have fever and/or significant pyuria, which makes pyelonephritis unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Appendicitis is the most common nonobstetrical indication for abdominal surgery in pregnant women. However, the classic presentation consists of new-onset abdominal pain that begins diffusely in the periumbilical area and subsequently migrates to the right lower quadrant. Nausea, vomiting, fever, and reduced appetite are also often present. Although appendicitis may also manifest in a nonclassic fashion, e.g. with the kind of pain described here, it is not the most likely explanation for this patient's condition. Additionally, it would not explain her dysuria and hematuria.
questions.hint: This condition is more common among dehydrated individuals and those who use loop diuretics and antacids.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of left flank pain and bloody urine for the past 12 hours. She has not had a fever, chills, vomiting, or diarrhea. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Current medications include folic acid. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft and gravid abdomen with normal bowel sounds. There is guarding on the left lateral side and tenderness to palpation over the left costovertebral angle. Urinalysis shows hematuria but no proteinuria or pyuria. Ultrasonography of the kidneys shows a 4 mm stone in the left proximal ureter with mild hydronephrosis. The patient successfully passes the stone the next day and it is found to be composed of calcium and oxalate. At a follow-up evaluation one week later, the patient inquires about measures to prevent recurrence of kidney stones. In addition to adequate hydration, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the intestinal lumen, calcium binds to oxalate, which is then excreted in the feces. A low-calcium diet decreases intestinal excretion of oxalate, freeing up more for absorption. As a result, the increased urinary oxalate binds more calcium in the renal tubule, which can precipitate calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stones. Therefore, this patient would not benefit from a low-calcium diet.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics can be used for prophylaxis of recurrent calcium-containing stones in the general population. Thiazides are primarily indicated for patients with hypercalciuria, as they increase calcium reabsorption from the renal tubule, which decreases the amount of tubular calcium available for precipitation and stone formation. Diuretics are generally avoided in pregnancy because of the increased risk of dehydration and volume depletion. Additionally, thiazide diuretics in particular can cause fetal side effects such as thrombocytopenia, hypoglycemia, and hyponatremia. Furthermore, thiazide diuretics should only be considered to prevent stone recurrence after conducting a metabolic evaluation, which is not routinely performed in first-time stone formers.

C) INCORRECT:

A high-oxalate diet is a risk factor for the development of kidney stones. Increased oxalate consumption leads to hyperoxaluria, which in turn can bind to calcium in the renal tubule and precipitate into calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stones (80%). Therefore, a low-oxalate diet would be recommended for this patient to decrease her risk of nephrolithiasis.

D) CORRECT:

The consumption of animal protein is associated with increased urinary calcium, which can precipitate calcium stones; both calcium oxalate (most common) and calcium phosphate types. Therefore, this patient should be advised to reduce their intake of animal protein. Other conservative measures for calcium stones include generous hydration (the most important intervention; fluid intake should be ≥ 2.5 L/day), a low-sodium diet (prevents dehydration), and reduced consumption of oxalate-rich foods. In patients with recurrent calcium-containing stones with idiopathic hypercalciuria, thiazide diuretics (increase tubular reabsorption of Ca2+, which decreases urinary Ca2+) and urine alkalinization (e.g., with potassium citrate) can be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C supplementation is unlikely to benefit this patient. Excess vitamin C is excreted in the urine in the form of oxalate, which precipitates with calcium in the renal tubule, thereby increasing the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation.
questions.hint: The preventative measure targets the amount of calcium that is excreted in the urine.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute onset of left flank pain radiating to his inner groin and scrotum for 3 hours. He also has had nausea and one episode of hematuria. His only medication is a multivitamin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the left costovertebral area. He has normal skin turgor and a capillary refill time of < 1 second. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Calcium
9.5 mg/dL


Phosphorus
4.3 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL


Urine



pH
6.5


RBCs
50–60/hpf


A CT scan of the abdomen shows a 4-mm stone in the left distal ureter. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun and treatment with tamsulosin and ketorolac is initiated. Five hours later, he passes the stone. Metabolic analysis of the stone is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uric acid stones more frequently form in patients who are dehydrated or have gout. Although uric acid stones are radiolucent on plain x-ray they can be seen on a CT scan. However, a uric acid stone is very unlikely as these stones are uncommon (< 5% of all kidney stones), and the patient has no signs of dehydration or gout.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnesium ammonium phosphate kidney stones, also known as struvite stones, are caused by infection with urease-producing organisms (e.g., Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus) within the urinary tract. They account for ∼ 15% of kidney stones and tend to fill the renal pelvis. This patient does not have a history of UTI nor is the imaging consistent with a struvite stone.

C) INCORRECT:

Cystine stones result from an autosomal recessive defect in transporter proteins of the proximal convoluted tubules, which impairs cystine reabsorption. This condition is known as cystinuria. The increased urinary cystine results in stone formation. Although a cystine stone is possible, it is very unlikely since it makes up < 1% of all kidney stones. Additionally, urinalysis would have shown elevated levels of amino acids lysine, ornithine, and/or arginine as they share the same transporter protein with cystine and their reabsorption is typically also affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Hereditary xanthinuria is a very rare autosomal recessive condition that leads to the accumulation and deposition of xanthine in the kidneys. More than half of affected patients develop nephrolithiasis before the age of 10 years. The remainder usually present with nephrolithiasis later in adolescence. Xanthine deposition is an unlikely cause for kidney stones, particularly for a patient in his 30s without a history of nephrolithiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Calcium kidney stones, most commonly composed of calcium oxalate, account for 80% of kidney stones. Hyperoxaluria resulting from excessive dietary intake of vegetables containing oxalate (e.g. beets, beans, spinach), excessive vitamin C, or bile acid malabsorption (e.g. Crohn disease) can cause these stones to form. This patient's consumption of high dose vitamin C (given his multivitamin intake) has most likely contributed to the development of a kidney stone.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
questions.hint: This is the most common type of kidney stone.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right-sided back pain, nausea, and dark urine. He reports alternating episodes of decreased urine output followed by a temporary increase in urine output for the past 2 days. In the past year, he has had two urinary tract infections. He has Crohn disease and underwent a small bowel resection 5 years ago. He currently takes mesalamine and a multivitamin. His father had recurrent kidney stones. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 70 RBC/hpf and envelope-shaped crystals. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a 6-mm stone in the proximal right ureter and two 4-mm stones in the left kidney. Which of the following factors has most likely contributed most to this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A parathyroid gland adenoma could cause pathologically increased secretion of parathyroid hormone and lead to clinical hyperparathyroidism. This often results in hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria, which contribute to calcium stone formation. These stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate stones, but the risk of calcium phosphate stones is also increased. This patient does not have any other symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., weakness, constipation, irritability), making hyperparathyroidism less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Excess vitamin D is unlikely in this patient with a history of Crohn disease and bowel resection. Both of these factors are more likely to cause vitamin D malabsorption, in which low to normal levels of vitamin D would be expected. Although he is currently taking a vitamin supplement, it is unlikely to have caused hypervitaminosis D or to be contributing to the development of nephrolithiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective tubular amino acid reabsorption is the underlying cause of cystinuria, an autosomal recessive disorder that increases the risk of cystine stones. This patient's father had recurrent kidney stones. However, in cystinuria, stone formation would typically manifest in childhood and hexagon-shaped crystals would be seen on urinalysis, rather than the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Furthermore, a positive sodium nitroprusside test would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) increase the risk of struvite stones. This patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections; however, they are unlikely to be the cause of his stones. Struvite stones would appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lid appearance) on urinalysis, not the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Furthermore, struvite stones are often quite large and fill the entire renal pelvis and calyces on imaging studies.

E) CORRECT:

Malabsorption of fatty acids due to deficiency in bile acids is common in patients with Crohn disease (and/or short bowel syndrome) and likely explains this patient's nephrolithiasis. In the intestinal lumen, undigested fatty acids chelate calcium, which would normally bind oxalate and lead to its excretion in the feces. Patients with Crohn disease often have pathologically increased luminal oxalate and increased oxalate absorption. After entering the serum, oxalate is excreted in the urine (hyperoxaluria), where it binds calcium and forms calcium oxalate stones.

Episodes of increased urination followed by oliguria are caused by temporary ureteral obstruction by stones. If a ureter is blocked, urine cannot pass through. When the obstruction is relieved, copious urine flows into the bladder.

F) INCORRECT:

High urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of calcium phosphate stones, which appear as wedge-shaped prisms on urinalysis. An alkaline environment increases the concentration of dibasic phosphate (HPO42-) in the urine, which is prone to bind to dicationic calcium (Ca2+) to form calcium phosphate stones. A high urine pH is also a risk factor for the formation of struvite stones, which appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lids) on urinalysis. In contrast, a low urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of oxalate stones.
questions.hint: Envelope-shaped crystals on urinalysis indicate calcium oxalate crystals.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of cramps and left-sided flank pain, nausea, and urinary frequency for 3 hours. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He drinks 2–3 alcoholic beverages daily. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows left costovertebral angle tenderness. An x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Abdominal ultrasound shows a 4-mm stone in the distal left ureter and a scatter of small stones in the left renal pelvis. Urinalysis shows RBCs and rhomboid-shaped crystals, but no WBCs. Pain medication and intravenous fluids are administered. In addition to adequate hydration, this patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Probenecid is a uricosuric agent often used in combination with allopurinol for the treatment of patients with chronic gout. Uricosuric agents are known to cause uric acid kidney stones, so probenecid would be contraindicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C can increase urinary excretion of oxalate and therefore should be avoided in patients with calcium oxalate stones. This patient's kidney stones are likely made of uric acid, so reducing vitamin C consumption would be unlikely to have significant benefits.

C) CORRECT:

Although most kidney stones are visible on x-ray, uric acid stones are radiolucent. They can be visualized on ultrasound or CT scan. Uric acid stones are usually soluble in alkaline urine. Thus, this patient should be treated with potassium citrate for urine alkalinization to help dissolve current stones and prevent the formation of new ones. Alternatively, sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate can be used to alkalinize the urine. He should also be advised to decrease his daily alcohol intake.

Uric acid stones are typically pleomorphic (e.g., rounded rhomboids, rosettes) on urinalysis, while uric acid crystals are needle-shaped in gout.

D) INCORRECT:

High-protein diets are strongly associated with the formation of both uric acid and calcium oxalate stones, secondary to urine acidification and increased urinary excretion of oxalate, respectively. Therefore, a low-protein, rather than high-protein diet, would be recommended for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of infections by urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum. Although these bacteria are known to cause kidney stones (specifically, struvite stones), this patient has no bacteria or WBC on urinalysis and lacks symptoms suggestive of a urinary tract infection. Ciprofloxacin is therefore unlikely to be beneficial in this case. In addition, struvite stones are weakly radiopaque and appear as rectangular prisms on urinalysis.

F) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) can be used for the prevention of calcium-containing kidney stones in patients with hypercalciuria, as it decreases calcium excretion in the urine. Calcium-containing stones are radiopaque and appear as either wedge-shaped prisms (calcium phosphate stones) or bipyramidal envelopes/biconcave dumbbells (calcium oxalate stones) on urinalysis. HCTZ is not indicated for patients with uric acid stones. Thiazide and loop diuretics are associated with hyperuricemia and would therefore increase the risk of uric acid stone formation.

G) INCORRECT:

Cranberry juice can help to acidify the urine, and so can be used for the prevention of calcium phosphate stones and struvite stones, as they are both associated with a high urine pH. Both types of stones are radiopaque. This patient's stones are likely made of uric acid, which is associated with a low urine pH, so urine acidification with cranberry juice would be counteractive in the treatment and prevention for this case.
questions.hint: Urinary calculi that are radiolucent on x-ray and appear as rhomboid-shaped crystals on urinalysis are most likely composed of uric acid.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressure readings during her last two visits. After her last visit 2 months ago, she tried controlling her hypertension with weight loss before starting medical therapy, but she has since been unable to lose any weight. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 154/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg on the left arm. She agrees to start treatment with a thiazide diuretic. In response to this treatment, which of the following is most likely to decrease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics increase rather than decrease serum uric acid levels by competing for the same binding site in the renal tubule transporters. Furthermore, the diuretic effect of thiazides leads to plasma volume depletion (dehydration) with subsequent hemoconcentration and increase of uric acid.

B) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) can increase serum calcium levels by decreasing the excretion of calcium in the urine. Other adverse effects include hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. The inhibition of renal Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule causes a net urine loss of positive ions such as sodium. This is compensated by increased renal tubular reabsorption of calcium to maintain electrochemical balance. Thiazide diuretics are used mainly in the treatment of hypertension, but their effect on serum and urinary calcium concentration can also be used for management of osteoporosis and for prevention of calcium kidney stones.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide and most other diuretics decrease serum sodium concentration by increasing loss of sodium in the urine. The diuretic effect of thiazides is due to decreased reabsorption of renal Na+, which creates an osmotic gradient for fluid to be excreted in the urine.

D) INCORRECT:

Rather than decrease serum glucose levels, thiazide diuretics worsen insulin resistance, which in turn increases serum glucose levels. Moreover, the plasma volume loss resulting from diuretics reflexively activates the sympathetic system, which, in turn, also contributes to an increase in serum glucose levels by activating gluconeogenesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rather than decrease lipid levels, thiazide diuretics increase total serum cholesterol levels, mildly increase low-density lipoproteins, and increase triglyceride levels. Thiazides do not have a substantial effect on high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Rather than decrease potassium excretion, thiazides and most other diuretics (except potassium-sparing agents) increase potassium excretion in the urine due to increased exchange of potassium for sodium via the Na+-K+ cotransporter in the late distal tubule. To avoid hypokalemia, thiazide diuretics may be combined with potassium-sparing diuretics.
questions.hint: Thiazide diuretics act by inhibiting Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule of the kidney.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of severe left-sided colicky flank pain that radiates towards his groin. He has vomited twice. Last year, he was treated with ibuprofen for swelling and pain of his left toe. He drinks 4-5 beers most days of the week. Examination shows left costovertebral angle tenderness. An upright x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows an 9-mm stone in the proximal ureter on the left. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on urinalysis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

RBC casts on urinalysis can be found in glomerulonephritis, glomerular ischemia, or malignant hypertension, none of which is present in this patient. Although kidney stones commonly present with hematuria secondary to epithelial irritation or injury, RBCs would not form into RBC casts.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine sediment (phase-contrast microscopy)

A tubular cast (blue overlay) is visible in the center of the image. The cast is composed of numerous RBCs, identifiable by their characteristic biconvex shape (examples outlined in yellow), in a matrix of fibrin and plasma proteins. Several epithelial cells surrounding the RBC cast are also visible.

RBC casts in urinary sediment are typically seen in glomerulonephritis.

B) CORRECT:

Rhomboid or needle-shaped crystals on urinalysis are characteristic of uric acid stones, which usually form in acidic urine as a result of uric acid precipitation in the renal tubules. Only uric acid forms radiolucent stones, which is most consistent with this patient's findings.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

C) INCORRECT:

Wedge-shaped crystals on urinalysis is consistent with calcium phosphate stones. These type of stones are usually seen in patients with hyperparathyroidism, and/or type 1 renal tubular acidosis. Unlike in this patient's presentation, calcium phosphate stones would be radiopaque and are not associated with gout.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph showing crystals with the appearance of wedge-shaped prisms (can also be described as blunt-ended needles), some bound together forming a rosette.

D) INCORRECT:

Coffin-lid-like crystals is consistent with struvite stones. These type of stones are usually associated with use of indwelling catheters, and upper urinary tract infection with urease-producing organisms such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, Providencia, Enterobacter, and Ureaplasma urealyticum. This patient with no evidence of UTI (e.g., dysuria, frequency, burning) is highly unlikely to have struvite stones. In addition, struvite stones are radiopaque, and would be seen on plain x-ray.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 9 (light microscopy)

Multiple coffin-shaped clear rectangular prisms are visible.
Numerous RBCs (biconvex anucleate cells) and WBCs (round nucleated cells) are also visible, indicating a concurrent UTI.

These coffin-shaped crystals are struvite crystals, which typically develop in alkaline urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Hexagon-shaped crystals are pathognomonic of cystinuria. Cystine stones are radiopaque, and would be seen on an plain x-ray. In addition, unlike this patient's first presentation at the age of 48, cystinuria usually manifests with recurrent stones beginning in childhood and is associated with a family history.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cystine crystals from a canine urine sample (1000x magnification)

A clump of multiple, clear, hexagon-shaped crystals is visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of cystine crystals.
questions.hint: This is a radiolucent ureteral stone in a patient with a likely history of gout (pain of the left toe indicating podagra), which occurs when an excess of uric acid in the blood builds up in joints and is excerbated by alcohol consumption. The same process may also lead to the formation of uric acid stones under certain conditions.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with Burkitt lymphoma is brought to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, flank pain, and dark urine for 1 day. Two days ago, he began induction chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisolone, and doxorubicin. Urinalysis shows 3+ blood and the findings in the photograph. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Free radical neutralization is the mechanism of action of amifostine. Free radical scavengers such as amifostine are used to prevent nephrotoxicity in patients receiving platinum-based alkylating agents (e.g., cisplatin) but are not used to treat or prevent urate nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of DNA gyrase is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), which are used to treat urinary tract infections such as pyelonephritis. Although pyelonephritis can manifest with flank pain, nausea, and hematuria, the presence of urate crystals indicates a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

The use of recombinant uricase and xanthine oxidase inhibitors can prevent urate nephropathy caused by tumor lysis syndrome. Recombinant uricase (e.g., rasburicase, pegloticase) oxidizes urate to allantoin, which is highly water-soluble and excreted in the urine without forming stones. Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol, febuxostat) decrease the serum concentration and urinary excretion of urate by blocking the formation of urate from xanthine and hypoxanthine.
Image Description:

Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of urate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule is the mechanism of action of probenecid, which is used to prevent chronic gout. However, since probenecid is a uricosuric drug, it would increase rather than decrease the risk of urate nephropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

The consumption of betaine or cranberry juice acidifies the urine, helping to prevent the formation of calcium phosphate and struvite stones, which precipitate in an alkaline environment. Calcium phosphate crystals are wedge- or rosette-shaped and struvite crystals are hexagonal. Uric acid stones precipitate in an acidic environment and urine acidification would increase rather than decrease the risk of urate nephropathy.
questions.hint: Hematuria and rhomboid crystals in the urine are consistent with urate nephropathy, which can occur after chemotherapy as a consequence of hyperuricemia in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 14-hour history of left flank pain associated with dark urine. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F). The abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds. There is guarding on the left lateral side and tenderness to palpation over the left costophrenic angle. An x-ray of the abdomen shows an 8-mm kidney stone. In addition to adequate hydration, which of the following changes in diet should be advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased oxalate consumption can cause hyperoxaluria. The increased urinary oxalate binds more calcium in the renal tubule, which can precipitate calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stone. Therefore, a low-oxalate diet would be recommended for this patient to decrease her risk of nephrolithiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C supplementation is unlikely to benefit this patient. Excess vitamin C is excreted in the urine in the form of oxalate, which precipitates with calcium in the renal tubule, thereby increasing the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation.

C) CORRECT:

The consumption of animal protein is associated with increased urinary calcium, which can precipitate calcium stones; both calcium oxalate (most common) and calcium phosphate types. Therefore, this patient should be advised to follow a low-protein diet. Other conservative measures for calcium stones include generous hydration (the most important intervention; fluid intake should be ≥ 2.5 L/day), analgesia (mainly acetaminophen), thiazides (increase tubular reabsorption of Ca2+, which decreases urinary Ca2+), alkalinization (e.g., with potassium citrate), a low-sodium diet (prevents dehydration), and reduced consumption of oxalate-rich foods.

D) INCORRECT:

In the intestinal lumen, calcium binds to oxalate, which is then excreted in the feces. A low-calcium diet decreases intestinal excretion of oxalate, freeing up more for absorption. As a result, the increased urinary oxalate binds more calcium in the renal tubule, which can precipitate calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stones. Therefore, this patient would not benefit from a low-calcium diet.

E) INCORRECT:

High sodium levels ultimately cause an increase in urine output, which results in both dehydration and increased amounts of calcium excreted in the urine. This increases the risk of calcium phosphate stones or calcium oxalate stones formation. This patient would benefit from a low-sodium, not a high-sodium, diet.
questions.hint: This patient presents with classic clinical features of nephrolithiasis, including unilateral flank pain, hematuria (dark urine), and costovertebral angle tenderness. The x-ray findings of a radiopaque stone indicate that it is most likely a calcium stone (80% of kidney stones).

questions.text: A previously healthy 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of several hours of severe, right-sided, colicky flank pain that radiates to the groin. He drinks 2–3 energy drinks daily. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a 4-mm radiopaque mass in the right ureter. Microscopic examination of the urine shows biconcave, dumbbell-shaped crystals. Which of the following is most likely to prevent future episodes of flank pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics inhibit reabsorption of calcium in the loop of Henle, causing hypercalciuria, which promotes calcium stone formation. Thiazide diuretics, however, increase calcium reabsorption in the renal tubules and decrease urinary calcium levels, which prevents the formation of calcium stones.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate crystallizes in an acidic environment and is soluble in an alkaline environment. In a patient with calcium oxalate stones, alkalinization of urine would prevent recurrent stone formation. This can be achieved with a diet rich in fruits and vegetables or potassium citrate. Urinary acidification is recommended for prevention of calcium phosphate or struvite stones.

C) CORRECT:

Inadequate hydration causes supersaturation of solutes in urine, which increases the risk of stone formation. Fluid intake of ≥ 2.5 L/day reduces the risk of recurrent nephrolithiasis because it decreases the urinary solute concentration and increases the frequency of urination. Adequate hydration prevents recurrence of all types of urinary stones. This patient should also be advised against excessive consumption of energy drinks, which often contain oxalate and contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

Calcium oxalate stones can also appear as bipyramidal envelopes on urinalysis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, which is then excreted in urine. High doses of supplemental vitamin C cause oxalate supersaturation in urine, which promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Starting this patient on supplemental vitamin C is therefore not the best course of action.

E) INCORRECT:

Restricting normal dietary calcium intake (approx. 1000 mg/day) enhances the intestinal absorption of oxalate. This increases urinary oxalate excretion and the risk of recurrent calcium oxalate stones. In addition, prolonged low dietary calcium can decrease bone mineral density and cause osteoporosis. However, supplemental calcium intake (above the normal daily requirements) should be restricted in patients with calcium stones.

F) INCORRECT:

Although the association between caffeinated beverages and formation of renal stones is not entirely clear, increased (not decreased) caffeine consumption (either coffee or tea) decreases the recurrence rate of nephrolithiasis, most likely by improving urinary flow and decreasing urinary supersaturation. Coffee and tea also have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that potentially reduce the risk of stone formation.
questions.hint: The radiopaque mass in the area of the ureter and biconcave dumbbells on urinalysis confirm the diagnosis of calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right flank pain that radiates to the groin. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. A urine dipstick is positive for blood. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following sets of laboratory findings?



Serum Ca2+

Serum uric acid
Urine Ca2+

Urine pH
Urine cystine



A
Normal
normal
increased
decreased
normal


B
Normal
normal
normal
normal
normal


C
Normal
normal
normal
increased
normal


D
Normal
increased
normal
decreased
normal


E
Increased
normal
increased
increased
normal


F
Normal
normal
normal
decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Calcium oxalate stones are overall the most common stone seen in nephrolithiasis and idiopathic hypercalciuria is the most common risk factor for this type of stone formation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show hypercalciuria and decreased urine pH; serum calcium and uric acid would be expected to be normal. Other risk factors for the development of calcium oxalate stones include Crohn disease, ethylene glycol toxicity, hypocitraturia, and vitamin C toxicity.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal stones typically form when there are one or more predisposing factors favoring precipitation of salts (e.g., urinary supersaturation due to ↓ urinary flow or ↑ renal excretion of solutes, alterations in normal urinary pH due to hyperuricemia, drugs, or infections). Healthy individuals who are not on any medication and who have normal levels of serum calcium, serum uric acid, urine calcium, and urine cystine, as well as a normal urine pH, are unlikely to develop renal stones.

C) INCORRECT:

Alkaline urine with otherwise normal lab values would be consistent with a patient with struvite stones. Alkaline urine is typically seen in patients with UTIs caused by urease-producing organisms, which convert urea to the basic compound ammonia. Ammonia combines with water to form ammonium, which under basic conditions combines with phosphate and magnesium to form struvite stones. Struvite stones are rare and only account for 5–10% of all kidney stones. This patient lacks a history of recurrent UTI or indwelling urinary catheter and therefore is unlikely to have struvite stones.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 9 (light microscopy)

Multiple coffin-shaped clear rectangular prisms are visible.
Numerous RBCs (biconvex anucleate cells) and WBCs (round nucleated cells) are also visible, indicating a concurrent UTI.

These coffin-shaped crystals are struvite crystals, which typically develop in alkaline urine.

D) INCORRECT:

These lab results would be seen in patients with uric acid stones, an uncommon type of nephrolithiasis (∼ 5-10%) primarily seen in patients with underlying hyperuricemia (e.g., tumor lysis syndrome, gout) and hyperuricosuria. Low urine pH favors the formation of uric acid stones. This patient does not have a history of any condition that would predispose her to uric acid stone formation and a different set of findings is more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

E) INCORRECT:

These lab results would be seen in a patient with calcium phosphate stones, the second most common type of calcium kidney stone. Etiological factors for calcium phosphate stones include hypercalciuria (e.g., idiopathic or due to hyperparathyroidism) and hypocitraturia. Serum calcium is usually normal in patients with calcium stones, but it can be elevated, especially if hyperparathyroidism is the underlying cause. Calcium phosphate stones precipitate in alkaline urine (e.g., as in renal tubular acidosis). This patient does not have any history of risk factors for calcium phosphate stone formation and a different set of findings is more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

These lab results would be seen in patients with cystine stones, which account for ∼ 1% of kidney stones and are typically only seen in patients with cystinuria. Cystinuria classically presents with recurrent nephrolithiasis beginning in childhood and is also characterized by impaired reabsorption of ornithine, arginine, and lysine. Cystine precipitates in acidic urinary pH and may form staghorn calculi. The absence of a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis or positive family history makes this set of findings unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's flank pain and hematuria are most likely due to nephrolithiasis. Urinary stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp pain in his left flank that began suddenly 30 minutes ago. Physical examination shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the left side. A photomicrograph of the urine is shown. The patient is most likely to benefit from an increase of which of the following components in the urine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An elevated urine sodium increases the risk of stone formation. Calcium is passively reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule with sodium and water. Therefore, a high serum sodium concentration will lead to decreased sodium reabsorption in the tubules, and both a parallel reduction in calcium transport and an increase of calcium excretion. In fact, patients with recurrent calcium stones are often recommended low-sodium diets to enhance sodium (and calcium) reabsorption.

B) CORRECT:

Hypocitraturia is a risk factor for the development of calcium oxalate stones. Calcium and citrate combine in the tubular lumen to form a soluble complex, which results in less free calcium available to combine with oxalate. An increase in urinary citrate through drug therapy or dietary modifications would be beneficial in this patient to reduce the risk of further stone formation.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.

C) INCORRECT:

An increase in H+ ions would not be beneficial in this patient because acidic urine promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones. In fact, urinary alkalinization (through dietary modification or medications) can be used as a treatment in patients with recurrent calcium oxalate stones.

D) INCORRECT:

An increase in urine oxalate excretion would further exacerbate this patient's calcium oxalate stones.

E) INCORRECT:

An increase in urinary phosphate would likely increase the risk of further stone formation since the majority of calcium oxalate stones are composed of some combination of phosphate.
questions.hint: This patient presents with flank pain radiating to the groin and costovertebral angle tenderness, indicating nephrolithiasis. Urinalysis shows “envelope-shaped” crystals, which are associated with calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of colicky abdominal pain for 1 day. She has had two similar episodes in the past. Urinalysis shows red blood cells and hexagonal-shaped crystals. Urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+
Urease-positive bacteria in the renal pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased stool fat content is a sign of decreased absorption of bile salts and can be caused by Crohn disease or short bowel syndrome. When there is increased stool fat content, calcium, which normally chelates free oxalate, binds free lipids instead. More free oxalate is absorbed, which promotes the formation of renal calcium oxalate stones. Oxalate stones are envelope-shaped and do not cause a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test, unlike what is seen in this case. In addition, this patient's young age and lack of fitting history rule out Crohn disease and short bowel syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+ can be seen in distal renal tubular acidosis. Patients with this condition are at increased risk for renal calcium phosphate stones due to an increased urine pH and increased bone turnover. Calcium phosphate stones are wedge-shaped prisms and do not explain a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test.

C) INCORRECT:

Homocystinuria is caused by enzyme deficiencies that increase blood and urine homocysteine levels. Although homocystinuria causes a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test, the condition is not associated with kidney stone formation.

D) CORRECT:

Autosomal recessive cystinuria is a hereditary defect of proximal convoluted tubule and small intestine amino acid transport proteins. These defects prevent proper reabsorption of ornithine, cystine, lysine, and arginine in the small intestine and the kidneys. This leads to the precipitation of hexagonal-shaped cystine stones in urine and a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test.

E) INCORRECT:

Urease-producing bacteria are a group of pathogens that can cause urinary tract infection and are responsible for forming ammonium magnesium phosphate stones, also called struvite stones. They account for about 15% of kidney stones and can even form staghorn calculi. Although this patient's abdominal pain could be a sign of a UTI, urease-producing bacteria show a negative urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test. Moreover, struvite stones are coffin lid shaped, rather than the hexagonal-shaped crystals seen here.
questions.hint: Colicky abdominal pain in a child with a positive sodium cyanide nitroprusside test, hexagonal-shaped crystals, and hematuria indicates cystine stones due to cystinuria.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with hypertension and gout comes to the physician with left flank pain and bloody urine for two days. He does not smoke cigarettes but drinks two beers daily. Home medications include hydrochlorothiazide and ibuprofen as needed for pain. Physical examination shows left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine dipstick is strongly positive for blood. Microscopic analysis of a stone found in the urine reveals a composition of magnesium ammonium phosphate. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Hereditary deficiency in amino acid reabsorption

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urinary tract infection is the strongest predisposing factor for the development of struvite stones. Urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) convert urea to ammonia, which then combines with magnesium and phosphate to form struvite stones. In severe cases, they can appear as staghorn calculi.

B) INCORRECT:

High supplemental vitamin C intake, as well as a diet rich in animal proteins, are predisposing factors for the development of hyperoxaluria and calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of nephrolithiasis. This patient instead presents with a struvite stone, making another etiology for his condition more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia (e.g., gout) is a predisposing factor for the development of uric acid stones but does not contribute to the development of struvite stones, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory bowel disease is a predisposing factor for the development of hyperoxaluria and calcium oxalate kidney stones, the most common type of nephrolithiasis. IBD does not contribute to the development of struvite stones, as seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Ethylene glycol poisoning may trigger the precipitation of oxalate crystals in the urine and can lead to the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Ethylene glycol ingestion would not cause a struvite stone, as seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

A genetic defect in amino acid reabsorption (cystinuria) causes aminoaciduria and cysteine accumulation in the urine and would increase the risk of developing cystine stones. This patient's urinary stone is composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate, not cystine. Also, cystinuria usually manifests during childhood.
questions.hint: This patient's flank pain and hematuria indicate nephrolithiasis. Struvite stones (magnesium ammonium phosphate stones) form when urine is alkaline.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of left-sided back pain with radiation to the groin that began 2 hours ago. She has had similar episodes in the past. Her pulse is 103/min. Examination shows a soft and non-tender abdomen. Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present. Leukocyte count is 11,000/mm3. Urine dipstick is positive for blood and a urinary cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient's urine is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urinary pH of 7.8 indicates alkaline urine, which is an important pathophysiological feature of calcium phosphate stones and struvite stones. While these stones can also manifest with episodic back pain, they are both radiopaque and would thus be seen on x-ray. Moreover, this young, otherwise healthy patient does not have significant risk factors for the development of alkaline urine, e.g., diuretic use or a urinary tract infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infection due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) is associated with the formation of struvite stones, which form as a result of the bacteria's urease activity and the subsequent increase in ammonia concentration in the urine. Struvite stones are classically radiopaque and thus would appear on x-ray. Moreover, in the case of struvite stones, a positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypocitraturia is associated with the formation of calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of stone seen in nephrolithiasis, as well as calcium phosphate stones. Calcium stones are virtually always radiopaque, whereas this patient has a stone that is not visualized on x-ray. Cystinuria is not associated with low urinary citrate levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricosuria would be expected with uric acid nephrolithiasis, which characteristically appears as rhomboid or needle-shaped crystals in the urine. Uric acid stones are classically radiolucent on x-ray and develop as a result of increased serum uric acid levels. Risk factors include Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a history of gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. Cystinuria is not associated with increased urine uric acid concentration.

E) CORRECT:

Hexagon-shaped crystals on urinalysis would be consistent with cystine stones caused by cystinuria. Cystinuria is due to a hereditary defect in both intestinal and renal amino acid transporters, which leads to impaired reabsorption of cystine (in addition to ornithine, arginine, and lysine) in the renal proximal convoluted tubule and subsequent precipitation of cystine stones. Cystine stones are only poorly radiopaque and often do not appear on x-ray. The positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test in this patient confirms the diagnosis.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cystine crystals from a canine urine sample (1000x magnification)

A clump of multiple, clear, hexagon-shaped crystals is visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of cystine crystals.
questions.hint: Flank pain radiating to the groin with costovertebral angle tenderness suggests nephrolithiasis. Recurrent radiolucent nephrolithiasis in a young adult with a positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test is consistent with cystinuria.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of right flank pain and nausea. Her only medication is a multivitamin. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness in the right costovertebral angle. Urinalysis shows a pH of 5.1, 50–60 RBC/hpf, and dumbbell-shaped crystals. Which of the following best describes the composition of the crystals seen on urinalysis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnesium ammonium phosphate kidney stones (struvite stone), which are typically caused by infection with urease-producing organisms (e.g., Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus), would be associated with alkaline urine and coffin-lid shaped crystals on urinalysis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 9 (light microscopy)

Multiple coffin-shaped clear rectangular prisms are visible.
Numerous RBCs (biconvex anucleate cells) and WBCs (round nucleated cells) are also visible, indicating a concurrent UTI.

These coffin-shaped crystals are struvite crystals, which typically develop in alkaline urine.

B) CORRECT:

Calcium oxalate stones, which are the most common type of renal stones, are radiopaque and associated with envelope- or dumbbell-shaped crystals on urinalysis. Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones include acidification of urine (e.g., excessive vitamin C intake), hypocitraturia (also often associated with decreased urine pH), hyperoxaluria due to excessive dietary intake of vegetables containing oxalate (e.g. beets, beans, spinach), gastrointestinal malabsorption (e.g., Crohn disease), and ethylene glycol poisoning. This patient's consumption of multivitamin tablets could have contributed to the development of a calcium oxalate stone. Small calcium oxalate stones can be treated medically with potassium citrate (to alkalinize the urine and increase urinary citrate), thiazide diuretics (to decrease calcium excretion in urine), and a low-sodium diet (to increase sodium and calcium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule).

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium phosphate stones are typically associated with alkaline urine pH and wedge-shaped prism crystals on urinalysis, unlike this patient with acidic urine and dumbbell-shaped crystals.

D) INCORRECT:

Acidic urine pH is a risk factor for cystine stones, which typically occurs in patients with cystinuria. However, the onset of urolithiasis with cystinuria usually occurs during childhood and patients with cystine stones would have hexagonal crystals on urinalysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ammonium urate stones are typically associated with neutral or alkaline urine pH and spherical bodies with irregular protrusions on urinalysis, unlike this patient with acidic urine and dumbbell-shaped crystals.
questions.hint: This is the most common type of kidney stone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician with right-sided flank pain and blood in her urine for 1 day. She does not have fever or dysuria. She had similar symptoms several weeks ago but did not seek medical care at the time. Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Her serum uric acid level is 6.9 mg/dL. Urine dipstick shows 3+ blood. Analysis of a 24-hour urine collection specimen shows wedge-shaped prisms. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following to prevent recurrence of her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A low-potassium diet has been associated with an increased risk of calcium nephrolithiasis, which this patient most likely has, as evident from the wedge-shaped prisms on urinalysis. Potassium increases urinary citrate excretion. Citrate binds to urinary calcium and forms soluble complexes that are then excreted. Thus, citrate prevents calcium supersaturation and stone precipitation. A high- rather than low-potassium diet (e.g., one rich in fruits) would be recommended in this patient to minimize the risk of recurrent calcium stone formation.

B) INCORRECT:

A high-protein diet increases urinary calcium excretion and is a risk factor for calcium nephrolithiasis, which this patient most likely has, as evident from the wedge-shaped prisms seen on urinalysis. The metabolism of animal protein generates amino-acids that decrease the plasma pH. To buffer this acidity, calcium is released from bone to increase plasma pH (bone buffering). This, in turn, increases renal calcium excretion. Thus, a low- rather than a high-protein diet would be recommended in this patient to minimize the risk of recurrent calcium stone formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, may be beneficial in the case of struvite stones, which are typically formed when there is an upper urinary tract infection caused by urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Ureaplasma urealyticum. Struvite stones appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lid crystals), unlike the wedge-shaped prisms seen in this patient. Thus, antibiotics would not be indicated in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a canine urine sample

Sample shows clear, euhedral, rectangular prism crystals (struvite crystals with their characteristic coffin-lid appearance (cf. illustration); examples indicated by green overlay) composed of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. In humans, struvite crystals are only seen in upper urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing organisms (e.g., Proteus or Klebsiella species).

D) INCORRECT:

Dietary calcium restriction is not routinely recommended in individuals with nephrolithiasis and mild hypercalciuria unless the urinary calcium levels are very high (i.e., >1500 mg/day). Decreased dietary calcium intake stimulates intestinal oxalate absorption, which, in turn, increases renal oxalate excretion (hyperoxaluria). Oxalate binds to calcium, forming calcium oxalate stones, which would be seen as bipyramidal crystals (envelope appearance) crystals on urinalysis. Although this patient does not have oxalate stones on urinalysis, decreasing calcium intake would increase her risk of developing oxalate stones. In addition, this patient's urinary calcium levels will need to be assessed before recommending a dietary calcium restriction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

E) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, decreases urinary uric acid levels and is indicated to prevent recurrent stone formation in patients with uric acid nephrolithiasis or in those with calcium nephrolithiasis and a high urinary uric acid level. Uric acid stones appear as rhomboid or needle-shaped crystals. Since this patient's urinalysis shows wedge-shaped prisms and normal serum uric acid levels, allopurinol would not be beneficial.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

F) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics, such as chlorthalidone, increase calcium reabsorption in the renal tubules and decrease hypercalciuria. In patients with recurrent calcium nephrolithiasis and, what is likely, hypercalciuria, a thiazide diuretic is indicated to decrease urinary calcium levels and minimize the risk of recurrent calcium stone formation.

Additional measures to prevent the formation of calcium phosphate stones include a low sodium diet, which enhances the effect thiazides have in promoting calcium reabsorption from the renal tubule, and urine acidification as calcium phosphate stones predominantly form in alkaline urine.
questions.hint: Flank pain, hematuria, and urine microscopy showing wedge-shaped prisms suggest a diagnosis of renal colic due to calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis. Recurrent renal colic in a patient with calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis is strongly suggestive of an underlying hypercalciuria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of worsening lower abdominal pain and nausea for the past 2 hours. He reports that the pain projects into his right groin and testis. One month ago, he woke up during the night because of similar pain in his right side. The pain became excruciating after 30 minutes and resolved spontaneously after 6 hours. He goes to the gym at least 6 days each week and started a new diet 3 months ago in an effort to build up muscle mass. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 133/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right side and reduced frequency of bowel sounds; guarding and rebound tenderness are absent. There is no swelling or erythema of the groin and scrotum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adynamic intestinal obstruction (paralytic ileus) results in reduced bowel sounds, abdominal pain, and nausea. However, in paralytic ileus, abdominal pain is caused by intestinal distention; it typically occurs days after the onset of paralytic ileus and is present diffusely in the abdomen; a paralytic ileus alone does not explain the hyperacute onset of lower abdominal pain, tenderness on the right side of the abdomen, or the radiation of pain to the groin and testis seen here. This patient has a mild paralytic ileus but his symptoms are caused by a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion can manifest with groin pain, nausea, and lower abdominal pain. Vigorous physical activity is a risk factor and patients might also report a similar episode in the past that resolved spontaneously (intermittent testicular torsion). However, in testicular torsion, the pain starts in the testicle and radiates to the abdomen, whereas the opposite is seen here.
