Moreover, other features of testicular torsion, including testicular swelling, testicular tenderness, and abnormal position of the testicle, would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection of the epididymis, most commonly caused by bacterial urinary tract infections or sexually transmitted infections, may manifest with unilateral scrotal pain, flank pain, and a low-grade fever. However, in epididymitis, the pain starts in the scrotum and may radiate to the ipsilateral flank, whereas the opposite is seen here. Furthermore, other features of infection of the epididymis, including scrotal swelling and scrotal erythema, are not seen in this patient. Finally, nausea, abdominal tenderness, and reduced bowel sounds are not typical features of epididymitis.

D) CORRECT:

Kidney stones classically manifest with nausea and sudden episodes of severe, unilateral abdominal and flank pain (renal colic) due to distention of the renal capsule and/or the ureter proximal to the obstruction. The pain radiates to the ipsilateral lower abdomen, groin, testicles (or labia majora in women), and perineum (typically T10–S4 dermatomes) as the stone migrates from the renal pelvis through the ureter. Occasionally, on abdominal palpation, there is also mild tenderness in the vicinity of the stone. The pain of renal colic increases steadily, typically reaches maximum intensity within 1–2 hours, and then plateaus until the stone leaves the ureter (usually after another few hours) or is removed. Although intermittent pain exacerbations (lasting several minutes) can occur as a result of ureteral peristalsis, the term renal “colic” is considered a misnomer because the pain does not cease completely in between exacerbations as it often does with intestinal colic. The passage of the stone into the bladder characteristically results in rapid relief from pain. The two episodes of renal colic in this patient resulted from two different ureteral stones; recurrence of urolithiasis is common.

Depending on the location of the stone, urolithiasis may resemble conditions such as appendicitis or testicular torsion. The reduced bowel sounds on auscultation of the abdomen most likely indicate that the patient has a mild adynamic ileus, which is a reflexive response to severe pain.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial, coronal, and sagittal planes) of a 54-year-old patient with a history of renal calculi

An obstructive calculus (green arrowhead) is present in the proximal left ureter. Pelvicaliectasis and ureteral dilatation (green overlay) are seen to the level of the calculus. There is a small amount of asymmetric fat and fascial stranding around the left kidney and proximal ureter as a result of edema.

Additional findings include a small hypodense right adrenal mass (yellow overlay), small hepatic hypodensities (example indicated by white arrowhead), a lumbosacral perineural (Tarlov) cyst (red overlay), and atherosclerotic calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

An incarcerated groin hernia (e.g., femoral hernia, inguinal hernia) can result in dragging groin pain, and weightlifting is a risk factor for hernia development. An incarcerated hernia can also cause nausea and abdominal pain as a result of mechanical bowel obstruction. However, a patient with mechanical bowel obstruction would have hyperactive rather than hypoactive bowel sounds, and there is no groin swelling in this patient to suggest a hernia. Moreover, the presence of tenderness on the right side of the abdomen, the previous episode of similar pain one month ago, and the pattern of change in pain intensity during the previous episode are not consistent with an incarcerated hernia.

F) INCORRECT:

Periappendiceal pus indicates an appendiceal abscess or a ruptured appendix, which are complications of appendicitis. While appendicitis may manifest with severe right-sided lower abdominal pain and tenderness (at the McBurney point) as well as nausea, other features of appendicitis (e.g., rebound tenderness, guarding, fever) would be expected. Furthermore, the radiation of pain into the right groin and testis, the previous episode of similar pain one month ago, and the pattern of change in pain intensity during the previous episode are not consistent with appendicitis.
questions.hint: A diet rich in animal protein (e.g., to build up muscle mass), which increases calcium and uric acid excretion and decreases the level of urinary citrate, is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of severe left flank pain that radiates to his left lower abdomen. The pain began while he was shopping for groceries and has steadily increased in intensity. He has never had similar pain in the past. He does not have chills, nausea, dysuria, or hematuria. He had a right inguinal hernia that was surgically treated 10 years ago. He has hypertension that is well-controlled with losartan. He does not smoke and drinks alcoholic beverages regularly. He appears anxious and restless. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/86 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender; bowel sounds are present. Urine studies show:


pH
4.4


RBC
15/hpf


RBC casts
negative


WBC
3/hpf


Protein
trace


Therapy with ibuprofen is initiated. The pain decreases substantially after 1 hour. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a stone measuring 4 mm in diameter in the left proximal ureter with no observed hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit the patient for percutaneous nephrolithotomy
Admit the patient for extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy
Admit the patient for therapeutic ureterorenoscopy
Recommend fluid intake and discharge the patient

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous nephrolithotomy is the first-line treatment for renal stones with a total stone burden > 20 mm (> 10 mm in the case of lower pole renal stones) or for stones that have a complex morphology or atypical composition (e.g., cystine stones, uric acid stones). Because this patient's ureteral stone measures < 10 mm, a different approach should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Emergent nephrostomy or ureteral stenting is indicated in urolithiasis complicated by hydronephrosis (i.e., severe obstruction) or infection (i.e., pyonephrosis) to provide surgical decompression prior to definitive stone treatment. This patient presents with an uncomplicated ureteral stone with no evidence of hydronephrosis or infection (e.g., fever or pyuria); therefore, emergent nephrostomy is not the most appropriate treatment in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a first-line treatment option for renal stones with a total stone burden ≤ 20 mm (≤ 10 mm in the case of lower pole renal stones). It can be used in proximal ureteral stones measuring > 10 mm as long as there are no contraindications to ESWL (e.g., concomitant urinary tract infection, bleeding diathesis). Because this patient's ureteral stone measures < 10 mm, ESWL is not the most appropriate next step in management.

D) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic ureterorenoscopy (URS) is a first-line treatment for renal stones with a total stone burden ≤ 20 mm (≤ 10 mm in the case of lower pole renal stones) and ureteral stones measuring > 10 mm (especially mid- or distal ureteral stones). Because this patient's ureteral stone measures < 10 mm, URS is not the most appropriate next step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin) are frequently used to treat complicated cystitis or uncomplicated pyelonephritis, and may also be indicated in patients with stones complicated by a UTI. This patient, however, has no signs or symptoms suggestive of a urinary tract infection (e.g., fever, dysuria, or pyuria).

F) CORRECT:

Conservative therapy (i.e., recommending fluid intake and discharging the patient with pain medications) is the most appropriate initial step in the management of a patient with an uncomplicated ureteral stone (i.e., absence of hemodynamic instability, urosepsis, acute renal failure, hydronephrosis) measuring ≤ 10 mm because these stones have a high rate of spontaneous passage. Medical expulsive therapy (MET) with alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin) or calcium-channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) can be offered to facilitate the passage of the stone, especially in patients with distal ureteral stones measuring 5–10 mm. There is no consensus on the optimal duration of MET but 4–6 weeks is usually preferred. Patients who are managed conservatively at home should strain their urine to recover the stone for further analysis. They should also be counseled to return for urologic evaluation if there is uncontrolled pain or if the stone does not pass.

Stone size and location determine the likelihood of spontaneous passage: Stones ≤ 5 mm tend to pass spontaneously, while stones > 10 mm are unlikely to do so, especially if located in the pyelon or proximal ureter.
questions.hint: In patients with symptomatic nephrolithiasis, initial management is guided by several factors, such as the presence or absence of complications (e.g., hemodynamic instability, urosepsis, acute renal failure, hydronephrosis) and the size and location of the stone.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of sudden, right-sided flank pain, nausea, and vomiting that started 4 hours ago. The pain radiates down to her groin. She has never had any similar episodes in the past. Two years ago, she had right upper quadrant abdominal pain and was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis, for which she underwent cholecystectomy. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and takes metformin. She drinks a glass of wine at dinner every day. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen without guarding. McBurney sign is negative. There are several well-healed laparoscopic abdominal incisions. There is tenderness to percussion at the right costovertebral angle. Urine studies show:


Blood
3+


Protein
1+


RBCs
5–10/hpf


WBCs
2/hpf


Casts
none


Nitrites
negative


Leukocyte esterase
negative


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the bladder and kidneys
X-ray of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder
Noncontrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the bladder and kidneys alone can be used as an initial imaging test for patients in whom radiation exposure should be minimized (e.g., in children, pregnancy). Moreover, because ultrasonography of the kidney has a high sensitivity to detect hydronephrosis, it is also used in the emergency department in patients with a known history of stone disease and recurrent flank pain in order to minimize cumulative radiation exposure. In most adult patients with the first instance of flank pain from suspected stone disease, such as this woman, radiation exposure from imaging is not a significant concern and a different imaging modality is preferred. Ultrasonography alone has a relatively low sensitivity for stone detection, especially for small stones and distal ureteric stones.

B) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (KUB) alone is not used for the initial diagnosis of nephrolithiasis because it has poor sensitivity in detecting very small stones and stones composed of cystine or uric acid (radiolucent on x-ray). Also, bowel contents can obscure the visualization of a stone by a KUB x-ray. This imaging modality is more commonly used to monitor patients with nephrolithiasis for stone passage rather than for initial diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Metabolic evaluation including serum calcium, phosphorus, uric acid, bicarbonate, PTH, and a twenty-four-hour urine profile, is indicated in patients with recurrent nephrolithiasis and high-risk, first-time stone formers (e.g., patients with a solitary or a transplanted kidney) to identify possible risk factors for stone formation (e.g., decreased urine pH, hypocitraturia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricemia, hyperparathyroidism). However, this is the patient's first episode of nephrolithiasis, and she is not considered high-risk; therefore, a metabolic evaluation is not indicated.

D) CORRECT:

A noncontrast CT scan (NCCT) of the abdomen and pelvis is the gold standard diagnostic exam for most adult patients with the first instance of sudden flank pain as it has a sensitivity and specificity of > 95% for the diagnosis of renal and ureteric stones. NCCT demonstrates the calculus location, size, density, and degree of obstruction (hydronephrosis); nearly all stones are radiopaque on NCCT. Renal ultrasonography (USG) with an x-ray of the kidney, ureter, and bladder (KUB) is not as sensitive as NCCT, especially for small stones. However, since most small stones are passed spontaneously, the combination of renal USG and KUB x-ray is a reasonable and cheaper initial imaging protocol to detect large stones (i.e., ones that might require removal) when NCCT is not available. In patients in whom radiation exposure should be minimized (e.g., children, pregnant patients), renal USG alone is the imaging modality of choice. In recent years, reduced-radiation NCCT has become available and can be safely used in children. NCCT also has the advantage of being able to detect atypical causes of flank pain such as diverticulitis and appendicitis.

A contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen and pelvis is only indicated when the initial NCCT cannot clearly differentiate between phleboliths and a stone. A CECT is also indicated when delineation of the urinary tract is required, as is the case with complex stones or patients with atypical anatomy (e.g., horseshoe kidney, transplanted kidney).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial, coronal, and sagittal planes) of a 54-year-old patient with a history of renal calculi

An obstructive calculus (green arrowhead) is present in the proximal left ureter. Pelvicaliectasis and ureteral dilatation (green overlay) are seen to the level of the calculus. There is a small amount of asymmetric fat and fascial stranding around the left kidney and proximal ureter as a result of edema.

Additional findings include a small hypodense right adrenal mass (yellow overlay), small hepatic hypodensities (example indicated by white arrowhead), a lumbosacral perineural (Tarlov) cyst (red overlay), and atherosclerotic calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelogram was once considered the initial imaging modality of choice in patients with nephrolithiasis as it provides a complete outline of the urinary tract, allows the identification of the obstruction, and detects hydronephrosis. However, it requires IV contrast and, in some cases, multiple films, which increases radiation exposure. Nowadays, intravenous pyelogram is not the most appropriate first-line imaging test for nephrolithiasis.

F) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is obtained in patients with nephrolithiasis and clinical or laboratory signs of a urinary tract infection, such as fever, dysuria, pyuria, positive leukocyte esterase, and positive nitrites, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: Sudden flank pain that radiates to the groin, hematuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness are highly suggestive of nephrolithiasis. Nausea and vomiting are reflexive responses to severe pain.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-hour history of severe right flank pain. He is nauseous and has vomited twice since the onset of his symptoms. He has no dysuria. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years and drinks 2–3 beers on weekends. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, metoprolol, and a vitamin C supplement. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 133/84 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft. There is tenderness to palpation at the right costovertebral angle. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, and nontender prostate. Urinalysis shows 17 RBCs/hpf. A nonenhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows a 7-mm stone in the distal right ureter without associated hydronephrosis. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and oral ibuprofen therapy are started. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate can be used in the treatment of uncomplicated upper urinary tract infections (UTIs), which can occur as a complication of urolithiasis. However, patients with upper UTIs typically present with fever, chills, dysuria, and pyuria. This patient has no signs or symptoms of a concomitant UTI that would warrant antibiotic treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Bethanechol, a parasympathomimetic agent, causes contraction of the detrusor muscle and is used in the treatment of urinary retention and neurogenic bladder. Bethanechol does not have any effect on ureter smooth muscle and would therefore not facilitate stone passage.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide can be considered for prophylaxis in patients with recurrent calcium-containing stones and idiopathic hypercalciuria. Patients taking vitamin C are at an increased risk of calcium-containing stones because vitamin C is converted to oxalate, excreted in the urine, and can bind with calcium to form calcium oxalate stones. Although this patient likely has a calcium oxalate stone, which is the most common type of stone, he presents with an uncomplicated ureteral stone for the first time and should receive treatment rather than prophylaxis for recurring stones.

D) INCORRECT:

Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) can be used in medical expulsive therapy to facilitate the passage of uncomplicated stones. However, diltiazem is a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that exerts its effects primarily on cardiac muscles, and it is most commonly used as an antihypertensive. Diltiazem has not been shown to be useful in the management of ureteral stones.

E) INCORRECT:

Mirabegron is a β3 adrenergic agonist that causes detrusor muscle relaxation and is used in the treatment of overactive bladder. However, mirabegron does not have any effect on the smooth muscle of the ureters and would therefore not facilitate stone passage.

F) CORRECT:

Tamsulosin, an α1-blocker, decreases ureteral smooth muscle contractions, which can facilitate the passage of ureteral stones and reduce the use of pain medications. α1-blockers and dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are the mainstays of medical expulsion therapy, which is the suggested treatment for ureteral stones ≤ 10 mm that are uncomplicated (e.g., in patients who are hemodynamically stable, have no signs of infection, and have no hydronephrosis). Uncomplicated stones < 5 mm typically pass spontaneously and do not require treatment. A urology consultation is necessary for patients with complicated stones (e.g., concomitant high-grade obstruction, urosepsis, impending acute kidney injury, intractable pain, vomiting) for discussion of noninvasive and surgical interventions.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral contrast; coronal plane)

A nonobstructive hyperdense calculus (red circle) is present in the left renal pelvis. Atherosclerotic calcifications (red arrowheads) of the abdominal aorta (red overlay) are also seen. Metal streak artifacts (white arrows) between the aorta and inferior vena cava (blue overlay) are caused by an internal spinal fixator.

K and dashed lines: kidney; Li: liver, Lu: lung; PM: psoas major muscle; S: stomach with oral contrast; UB: urinary bladder
questions.hint: This patient has a small distal ureteral stone and would benefit from an agent that facilitates stone passage.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man with a history of Crohn disease is found to have nephrolithiasis. He has had an ileocecal resection, and his disease remains intermittently active on medical therapy.
Which one of the following dietary recommendations is most appropriate to reduce this patient’s risk for future kidney-stone formation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reducing intake of fat, oxalate, and animal protein may reduce the risk for calcium oxalate stones.

B) CORRECT:

People with malabsorption of fatty acids are at risk for calcium oxalate kidney stones because of enteric hyperoxaluria. This can occur in the setting of inflammatory bowel disease, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, or terminal ileocecal resection, given that the terminal ileum is responsible for reabsorption of the majority of bile acids. Normally, calcium binds oxalate in the gastrointestinal tract and limits oxalate absorption in the colon. Two factors contribute to increased oxalate absorption when there is fatty-acid malabsorption: First, the fatty acids can bind to calcium, allowing free oxalate to be absorbed by the colon; second, the fatty acids can irritate the colon and allow increased oxalate absorption.

Increased dietary calcium intake binds to free oxalate and reduces its absorption, thereby reducing the risk for oxalate stones. A small increase in calcium absorption is outweighed by the fall in oxalate absorption. The associated gastrointestinal fluid losses in patients with malabsorption also contribute to the risk for kidney stones.

Key learning point: The dietary modification that can reduce the risk for formation of calcium oxalate kidney stones in a patient who has had a terminal ileocecal resection for Crohn disease is to increase intake of calcium.

C) INCORRECT:

Reducing intake of fat, oxalate, and animal protein may reduce the risk for calcium oxalate stones.

D) INCORRECT:

Reducing intake of fat, oxalate, and animal protein may reduce the risk for calcium oxalate stones.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is metabolized to oxalate, so increasing vitamin C intake would not reduce the risk for calcium oxalate stones and may even increase the risk.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and bilateral flank pain. His medical history is significant for multiple sclerosis, optic neuritis, a neurogenic bladder requiring intermittent catheterization, and recurrent urinary tract infections. He currently is taking interferon beta-1a and methylprednisolone for a recent flare of his optic neuritis.
On examination, his temperature is 38.5°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. He is diaphoretic and has warm extremities. He has bilateral costovertebral-angle tenderness to percussion.

Urine Gram stain shows many gram-negative bacilli.
An abdominal radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following substances is the most likely component of this patient’s kidney stones?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystine stones form in patients with cystinuria, which is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by hexagonal crystals in the urine. Cystine stones also form in an acid urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium phosphate stones also form in alkaline urine but rarely grow into a staghorn configuration. These stones may occur in a patient with a renal acidification defect that limits the ability to maximally acidify the urine but does not lead to an alkaline urine.

C) INCORRECT:

Uric acid stones form in acidic urine, whereas uric acid is much more soluble in an alkaline urine.

D) CORRECT:

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones account for 2% to 15% of all kidney stones and cause significant morbidity, including recurrent episodes of pyelonephritis and renal insufficiency. Struvite stones have also been called infection stones because they form in the presence of urea-splitting bacteria (such as Proteus or Klebsiella), which convert urine urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide via the enzyme urease. This leads to alkaline urine and elevated urinary ammonium levels, both of which are necessary for this type of stone formation. These stones can enlarge rapidly and fill the renal pelvis to form staghorn calculi. Treatment is very difficult and requires complete stone removal along with antibiotic therapy.

Key learning point: In patients with staghorn renal calculi and recurrent urinary tract infections, the calculi are most likely composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite).

E) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stone, do not typically cause staghorn calculi, and these stones usually form in an acid pH rather than an alkaline one.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset left-flank pain associated with urinary urgency and hematuria. Her medical history includes gout treated with allopurinol 300 mg daily, migraine headaches treated with topiramate 25 mg daily, and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. She also takes a vitamin D supplement, 1000 units daily, and has been taking guaifenesin during the past 10 days for a cough.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Urinalysis results showed a pH of 6.9 (reference range, 5.0–9.0), >100 red cells per high-power field (0–2), and 1–3 white cells per high-power field (0–2).
A radiopaque stone, 4 mm in diameter, is seen in the distal left ureter on abdominal radiography.
After the administration of intravenous fluid and analgesia, the stone is passed spontaneously. Analysis of the stone reveals that it consists of 100% calcium phosphate.
Which one of the following medications is most likely to have contributed to the formation of this patient’s calcium phosphate kidney stone?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D intoxication can cause nephrolithiasis, but high levels of vitamin D, calcium, and phosphorus are usually present.

B) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol may be used to treat kidney stones in patients who have high urinary uric acid that does not improve with increased fluid intake and alkalinization of the urine; it is not known to cause metabolic acidosis.

C) CORRECT:

Topiramate inhibits renal carbonic anhydrase in both proximal and distal renal tubules and can cause a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis. The ensuing metabolic acidosis is believed to increase the proximal reabsorption of citrate and reduce urinary citrate. Citrate is a natural stone inhibitor, as it chelates calcium in the urine and makes it more soluble. Hypocitraturia, in the setting of an increase in urinary pH that is seen from the bicarbonate loss with topiramate-induced proximal renal tubular acidosis, may lead to the formation of calcium phosphate stones. In addition, a metabolic acidosis tends to lead to liberation of calcium and phosphate when there is buffering by bone. This, in turn, leads to an increase in urinary calcium and phosphate, which may increase calcium phosphate supersaturation and crystallization.

Other causes of proximal renal tubular acidoses rarely cause kidney stones, whereas distal renal tubular acidosis often does because of the hypocitraturia, high urinary pH, and increased calcium and phosphate load from bone.

Key learning point: Topiramate, which inhibits carbonic anhydrase in both proximal and distal renal tubular cells, is associated with the development of calcium phosphate kidney stones; it can also cause a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although hydrochlorothiazide can cause hypercalcemia, it is used to prevent nephrolithiasis, because it decreases the urinary excretion of calcium.

E) INCORRECT:

Consumption of large amounts of guaifenesin has been associated with kidney stone formation; however, this is related to the crystallization of guaifenesin metabolites rather than to calcium phosphate stones or metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with severe right-flank pain radiating to the groin, intermittent episodes of gross hematuria, and right costovertebral tenderness. Her symptoms have lasted for 2 weeks.
The patient has a history of grade III obesity, for which she underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery 10 years ago. At age 35, she developed a kidney stone, went to an emergency department, and was treated conservatively with intravenous fluids and pain medication. Since then, she has had four additional kidney stones, none of which have been captured for analysis. She was advised to increase her fluid intake to help prevent future stones.
The patient has a pulse rate of 101 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 150/80 mm Hg, and a temperature of 37.0°C. Her BMI is currently 34.
Laboratory serum testing yields the following results: blood urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL (reference range, 10–20), creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (0.6–1.1), serum uric acid 5.5 mg/dL (1.5–6.0).
Urinalysis shows the following results:

A plain-film radiograph of the abdomen suggests numerous kidney stones. Noncontrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a 6-mm right-proximal ureteral stone with associated mild hydronephrosis. Multiple, bilateral kidney stones are also evident; the largest one measures 8 mm.
Which one of the following types of kidney stones is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients who have undergone Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery are at increased risk for developing calcium oxalate kidney stones. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery leads to malabsorption of free fatty acids and bile acids. The free fatty acids bind to calcium, thereby limiting the calcium available to bind to intestinal oxalate. In addition, the malabsorption of bile acids leads to colonic irritation and increases the permeability of the colon to oxalate, so there is an increase in absorption of unbound intestinal oxalate. The increase in urinary oxalate that results from gastrointestinal malabsorption is called enteric hyperoxaluria. Nephrocalcinosis and oxalate nephropathy can also occur. This complication does not occur with sleeve gastrectomy.

Key learning point: A patient who has undergone Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is at risk for kidney stones composed of calcium oxalate.

B) INCORRECT:

Uric acid stones form in acidic urine and have been reported after gastric bypass. The major risk factor for uric acid stones is low urinary volume, so patients who have severe malabsorption with considerable fluid losses are at risk for these types of stones. Uric acid stones occur far less often than calcium oxalate stones after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery and would not be evident on a plain-film radiograph of the abdomen.

C) INCORRECT:

Cystine stones occur in patients with cystinuria, a rare autosomal recessive disorder in which filtered cystine and dibasic amino acids are not reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium phosphate stones form primarily in alkaline urine and have not been associated with gastric bypass.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones typically form in the setting of recurrent urinary infection with urea-splitting bacteria.

Her current medications are extended-release nifedipine 30 mg daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily. Her blood pressure is 134/75 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 64 beats per minute. The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.

Noncontrast CT with 2-mm-slice width shows several 1- to 3-mm nonobstructing calyceal stones in both kidneys. No other abnormalities are noted.
Which one of the following management approaches is most likely to prevent further recurrences of this patient’s nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Potassium citrate is appropriate for patients with a low urine citrate level. It is also useful in conjunction with thiazide diuretics to offset hypokalemia that may develop from thiazides. Treatment with potassium citrate could predispose to the development of calcium phosphate stones in patients with an elevated urine phosphate level and alkaline urine. This is a concern in this patient, whose urine pH is above normal; potassium citrate is likely to raise the pH further and increase the risk of calcium phosphate precipitation.

B) INCORRECT:

A high-sodium diet can increase urine calcium and limit the efficacy of thiazide diuretics. Dietary sodium should therefore be limited to <2300 mg/day (100 mmol/day). This patient already follows a low-sodium diet (as evidenced by her 24-hour urine sodium level), so further restriction is unlikely to have a significant effect.

C) CORRECT:

Calcium stones are the most common types of kidney stones and can result from hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, hypocitraturia, or low urine volume. In a patient with a normal serum calcium level, hypercalciuria, and recurrent kidney stones of unknown composition, hypercalciuria is the most likely cause of the stones.

Thiazide diuretics, such as chlorthalidone, can reduce urine calcium levels and have long been the mainstay of pharmacologic therapy for treatment of kidney stones secondary to idiopathic hypercalciuria. Evidence of efficacy has been based on small studies or indirect evidence. Recently, a double-blind, randomized controlled study was conducted to evaluate increasing doses of hydrochlorothiazide in patients with recurrent calcium-containing kidney stones. The trial did not show a statistically significant improvement in symptomatic or radiologic recurrence of kidney stones over 3 years. This study was well conducted but has been criticized for the use of hydrochlorothiazide rather than a longer-acting thiazide diuretic and for the low doses used in most participants. In addition, not all patients enrolled had hypercalciuria, and dietary sodium was not well controlled. Thus, a long-acting thiazide is still considered the standard of care for treating hypercalciuria in a patient with recurrent kidney stones.

In addition to pharmacologic therapy, patients with kidney stones also benefit from dietary counseling:

• A high-sodium diet can increase urine calcium and limit the efficacy of thiazide diuretics. Dietary sodium should therefore be limited to <2300 mg/day (100 mmol/day). This patient already follows a low-sodium diet (as evidenced by her 24-hour urine sodium level), so further restriction is unlikely to have a significant effect.
• Diets high in oxalate-rich foods (such as spinach [but not kale], rhubarb, buckwheat, and almonds) can result in hyperoxaluria. A low-oxalate diet is unlikely to benefit this patient, who does not have a high urine oxalate level.
• Diets high in animal protein can lead to an increase in renal citrate absorption to offset the dietary acid load. Citrate is a natural stone inhibitor because it chelates calcium and makes it more soluble. Animal protein is also a source of uric acid, which can form the nidus of a calcium-containing stone.
• A low-calcium diet increases urine oxalate, thus paradoxically increasing the risk of stone formation, and is not advisable. Instead, age-appropriate dietary calcium intake is recommended.
• High fluid intake is important, as urine volume is essential to limit recurrences of nephrolithiasis.

Potassium citrate is appropriate for patients with a low urine citrate level. It is also useful in conjunction with thiazide diuretics to offset hypokalemia that may develop from thiazides. Treatment with potassium citrate could predispose to the development of calcium phosphate stones in patients with an elevated urine phosphate level and alkaline urine. This is a concern in this patient, whose urine pH is above normal; potassium citrate is likely to raise the pH further and increase the risk of calcium phosphate precipitation.

Key learning point: In a patient with recurrent kidney stones of unknown composition, hypercalciuria, and no other urine abnormalities, the risk for recurrent nephrolithiasis can be reduced by initiating treatment with a thiazide diuretic.

D) INCORRECT:

Diets high in oxalate-rich foods (such as spinach [but not kale], rhubarb, buckwheat, and almonds) can result in hyperoxaluria. A low-oxalate diet is unlikely to benefit this patient, who does not have a high urine oxalate level.

E) INCORRECT:

A low-calcium diet increases urine oxalate, thus paradoxically increasing the risk of stone formation, and is not advisable. Instead, age-appropriate dietary calcium intake is recommended.

An abdominal radiograph shows two radiopaque left kidney stones measuring 3 to 4 mm.
In addition to lifestyle interventions such as reduced sodium intake and increased fluid intake, which one of the following therapies should be recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine citrate can chelate calcium in the urine and serve as a natural stone inhibitor; it is usually prescribed as potassium citrate for patients with hypocitraturia and/or low urine pH, but this patient’s urine pH is slightly above the ideal range, and potassium citrate therapy may increase the risk for calcium phosphate precipitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is not used to prevent nephrolithiasis. This drug can cause renal tubular acidosis with a mixed defect such that there is both proximal wasting of bicarbonate and a defect in distal acidification. This combination can lead to calcium phosphorus stones and would be ill-advised in a patient with hypercalciuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Preventing episodes of symptomatic nephrolithiasis related to calcium-containing kidney stones (most commonly, calcium oxalate) requires a multitargeted approach. All patients should be encouraged to increase fluid intake with a goal of producing more than 2 liters of urine daily; meeting this goal may require 2.5 to 3 liters of daily fluid intake. In general, recommendations for patients with kidney stones include a low-sodium diet because urine sodium increases urine calcium. Ideally, the diet will also be rich in fruits and vegetables and low in animal protein, because diets that are high in animal protein tend to lead to hypocitraturia and an increase in urine uric acid and phosphate levels. Diets should also include age-appropriate calcium intake from food rather than reduced calcium intake.

D) CORRECT:

The most appropriate treatment for this patient with hypercalciuria is the initiation of a long-acting thiazide, such as chlorthalidone. These agents reduce urinary calcium excretion, an effect attributed to an increase in proximal tubule reabsorption of calcium.

Thiazide diuretics have been the cornerstone of pharmacologic therapy for treatment of kidney stones secondary to idiopathic hypercalciuria for decades, but there has been a paucity of data proving efficacy. Recently, a double-blind, randomized controlled study was conducted to evaluate increasing doses of hydrochlorothiazide in patients with recurrent calcium-containing kidney stones. The trial did not show a statistically significant improvement in symptomatic or radiologic recurrence of kidney stones over 3 years. This study was well conducted but has been criticized for the use of hydrochlorothiazide rather than a longer-acting thiazide diuretic and for the low doses used in most participants. In addition, not all patients enrolled had hypercalciuria. Patients with recurrent calcium stones and relatively high urine pH are challenging to manage, and a long-acting thiazide diuretic is still the best option for this situation.

Key learning point: The most appropriate medical therapy for a patient with recurrent nephrolithiasis due to hypercalciuria is a thiazide diuretic.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithotripsy is not indicated in asymptomatic patients with 3- to 4-mm stones, which are small enough to pass spontaneously.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of kidney stones presents for follow-up 5 days after a visit to the emergency department (ED) for right-sided flank pain and nausea. She was visiting her son in Arizona at the time, and a CT scan of her abdomen showed a small, solitary kidney stone in the right ureter. She received intravenous fluids and a dose of pain medication before being discharged; she passed the stone on her own one day later.
This is her third episode of kidney stones. The first occurred at age 44 and also involved an ED visit. The second occurred 2 months ago when she had right-sided pain and then passed a small stone 3 hours later while she was at home.
Today, she feels well and reports no hematuria, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her only complaint is a sore right heel from taking long hikes with her son. She reports that she has lost 3 kg during the past 4 months, which she attributes to dietary changes, including eating more leafy greens such as spinach and abstaining from red meat and alcohol.
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 117/72 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. She has a regular heart rhythm with no murmurs, and her lungs are clear to auscultation. She has no flank tenderness on palpation and no peripheral edema.
A basic metabolic panel yields the following results:

Sodium (mEq/liter)

What is the best next step in evaluating this patient’s recurrent nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with recurrent kidney stones, the goal of evaluation is to identify the type of stone to inform a plan for preventing further recurrence. The evaluation should include a focused history, metabolic panel, radiographic imaging with CT, stone analysis (if a stone is available), and 24-hour urine studies. In this case, the patient has already undergone the first three components of evaluation, and her history provides some possible clues to the recent recurrence:

• Her recent dietary changes, including increased intake of spinach, would have led to a higher oxalate intake, which could have led to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals.
• Her recent visit to Arizona, which has a hot, dry climate, may have predisposed her to volume depletion, which is another risk factor for kidney stone precipitation.

The next step is to conduct 24-hour urine studies to assess urine volume, pH, and excretion of calcium, uric acid, citrate, oxalate, sodium, potassium, magnesium, phosphate, and creatinine.

Stone retrieval for analysis would have been ideal but is not currently possible in this patient as she has already passed the stone. She should be advised to bring in any stones that she passes in the future so that they can be analyzed.

Key learning point: Evaluation of patients with recurrent kidney stones should include a focused history, metabolic panel, CT, 24-hour urine studies, and stone analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring parathyroid hormone levels is not indicated at this point because the patient’s calcium and creatinine levels are within normal limits. If the 24-hour urine collection reveals hypercalciuria, then measurement of the parathyroid hormone level would be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of 25-hydroxyvitamin D is not needed but would be appropriate if there were hypercalciuria, hypophosphatemia, or hyperparathyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Although radiographic imaging can be used to assess stone burden in patients with recurrent stones, CT is preferred over radiographs and has already been completed in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring the uric acid level would be helpful if this patient had a history of gout or other conditions that predisposed her to an acidic urine (e.g., chronic diarrhea, diabetes mellitus, or metabolic syndrome) as uric acid is more likely to precipitate in urine with a low pH. However, her history is more consistent with calcium oxalate stones, and a 24-hour urine study would be more helpful.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents for follow-up of recurrent nephrolithiasis. He has had three episodes to date: 3 months ago, 8 months ago, and 12 months ago. A stone submitted for analysis after the second episode was found to be composed of calcium oxalate crystals. The patient is not currently taking any medications or supplements and has no complaints.
Physical examination is unremarkable, as is a metabolic panel. Uric acid levels are within normal limits.
A 24-hour urine study done one week ago shows the following results:



Patient value
Ideal range in people with a history of kidney stones


24-hour urine volume (liters)

252

Potassium (mmol/24 hr)
52
20–100


In addition to increased fluid intake, what is the best next step to prevent further kidney stone formation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased fluid intake and sodium restriction are recommended for most patients with recurrent nephrolithiasis and have been shown to reduce recurrence of kidney stones. Data from this patient’s 24-hour urine collection support the use of these interventions. His 24-hour urine volume is only 0.8 liters, but the goal in patients with nephrolithiasis is at least 2 liters of urine daily, so he should be advised to increase his fluid intake. Usually, patients will need to drink 2.5 to 3 liters of fluid to achieve a urine volume of 2 liters because of insensible losses.

In addition, this patient’s urine sodium excretion (252 mEq/24 hr) is higher than the ideal (50–150 mEq/24 hr) for someone who is forming stones, reflecting a high dietary intake of sodium. A 24-hour urine sodium excretion of 252 mEq represents >5 grams of sodium intake (252 mEq x 23 mg/mEq = 5796 mg) daily, which is far greater than the daily recommended amount of 2300 mg. Dietary sodium restriction leads to an increase in reabsorption of sodium along with calcium in the proximal tubules, and this leads to a reduction in urine calcium levels, thus reducing the risk of recurrent kidney stones.

Key learning point: Two lifestyle interventions that can be initiated to prevent kidney stones are sodium restriction and increased fluid intake.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium restriction leads to an increase in the risk of stone formation rather than a decrease. This increased risk may be related to higher urine oxalate levels. When dietary calcium is restricted, less calcium is available in the intestinal lumen to bind oxalate and promote its excretion in the stool; this leads to higher oxalate absorption in the intestine and thus higher levels in both the serum and urine, resulting in more kidney stones. Instead, age-appropriate dietary intake of calcium (1000–1200 mg daily) is recommended. Whether dietary and supplemental calcium are equivalent in binding oxalate in the intestinal lumen is not clear.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose ascorbic acid, or vitamin C, is sometimes recommended to acidify the urine and treat recurrent urinary tract infections, although the evidence for this use is lacking. Vitamin C is not recommended for the treatment of kidney stones and has been shown to increase the risk of kidney stone formation in men; it should therefore be avoided. The exact mechanism underlying this increased risk is unclear but may be related to the fact that vitamin C is excreted in the urine as both its unmetabolized form and as oxalate.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has normal levels of uric acid in the urine without evidence of uric acid stones on analysis, so allopurinol is not indicated. Even if the level of uric acid in the urine was high, first-line treatment for uric acid kidney stones is to increase fluid intake and alkalinize the urine with medications such as potassium citrate. Allopurinol would be appropriate if this patient had high serum uric acid levels and recurrent gout.

E) INCORRECT:

Potassium citrate is not indicated in this case because the patient has normal urine citrate levels and does not have uric acid stones.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl reports several days of nonspecific right flank pain. Her family history is notable for kidney stones in both her father and paternal grandmother. A urine dip shows 1+ hematuria but is otherwise negative. Renal ultrasound demonstrates two hyperechoic areas in the right kidney with shadowing behind them but no anatomical abnormalities or evidence of obstruction. A metabolic panel, including calcium, is normal for the patient’s age.
Which one of the following tests should be the next step in this patient’s diagnostic workup?

choices.text: Spot urine collection for the calcium-to-creatinine ratio
Measurement of the parathyroid hormone level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 24-hour urine collection is typically done after the urinalysis and spot sample, but it is not the first step in evaluation because of the difficulty with obtaining an accurate collection. If the spot calcium-to-creatinine ratio is normal, a 24-hour collection is not needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing may be informative regarding the pathophysiology driving stone formation (e.g. hyperoxaluria or familial hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria), but it would not precede an initial evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has flank pain, and the ultrasound finding of hyperechoic regions with acoustic shadowing is consistent with kidney stones. Children with nephrolithiasis may present with abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, or both. Adolescents may have classic flank pain radiating to the groin, but complaints in younger children are often less specific.

The most common types of stones in children are calcium oxalate (45%–65%) and calcium phosphate (15%–30%). Risk factors for calcium-containing stones include low urine volume; high excretion of calcium, oxalate, uric acid, or some combination thereof; low excretion of citrate; and high urine pH (for calcium phosphate stones). Up to 50% of children presenting with nephrolithiasis have a positive family history. The incidence of nephrolithiasis has increased in both the pediatric and the adult population. This trend is thought to be related to changes in dietary habits, including an increase in sodium and animal-protein intake.

After history and physical examination, initial diagnostic evaluation for a child with suspected nephrolithiasis should include urinalysis, a spot urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio, a basic metabolic panel, and a renal ultrasound. The urinalysis will identify hematuria or evidence of a urinary tract infection and may provide additional clues regarding risk factors for nephrolithiasis, including the urine pH and the specific gravity (a proxy for the concentration of urine); even the presence of urinary crystals may suggest a specific etiology. The spot urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio can be used to screen for hypercalciuria, as it is easier to obtain a random sample than a 24-hour collection. A normal ratio for a child over 2 years of age is <0.2 mg/mg. The ultrasound may identify stones and is also useful to identify significant structural abnormalities that may lead to urinary stasis and stone formation.

Most stones smaller than 5 mm pass spontaneously. Those larger than 5 mm may require extracorporal shockwave lithotripsy, retrograde endoscopic lithotripsy, or percutaneous nephrolithotomy. For long-term management, children with nephrolithiasis should be encouraged to make the following dietary modifications:

• Ensure adequate fluid intake.
• Consume the age-appropriate recommended daily allowance of calcium, as current evidence does not support a link between reduced calcium intake and reduced risk of stone formation, and reduced calcium intake may increase the risk of osteopenia and secondary hyperoxaluria.
• Limit excessive consumption of oxalate (found in leafy vegetables, nuts, chocolate, dark tea, and almond milk).
• Avoid excessive intake of animal protein because it may increase excretion of calcium, oxalate, and uric acid — and decrease urinary citrate, which serves as a natural stone inhibitor by chelating urinary calcium.
• Avoid high-sodium diets because they lead to an increase in urinary calcium.

Additional recommendations may be tailored to the patient’s clinical presentation and course. If dietary changes are insufficient, hydrochlorothiazide can be added to the treatment regimen for patients with hypercalciuria because this agent reduces urinary excretion of calcium.

Key learning point: During an acute presentation for suspected urolithiasis, initial diagnostic evaluation should include urinalysis, renal ultrasound, and a spot urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the parathyroid hormone level is not indicated in this patient’s initial evaluation, given her normal serum calcium level, but would be appropriate if hypercalciuria were present.

E) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT can detect stones of every type and may be required for patients with pain or hematuria but no stone appreciated on ultrasound. This patient had stones identified on ultrasound and therefore does not require CT.

questions.text: A previously healthy 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute onset of left flank pain radiating to his inner groin and scrotum for 3 hours. He also has had nausea and one episode of hematuria. His only medication is a multivitamin. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the left costovertebral area. Urinalysis shows hematuria. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a 4-mm stone in the left distal ureter. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun and treatment with tamsulosin and ketorolac is initiated. Five hours later, he passes the stone. Metabolic analysis of the stone is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uric acid stones more frequently form in patients who are dehydrated or have gout. Although uric acid stones are radiolucent on plain x-ray they can be seen on a CT scan. However, a uric acid stone is very unlikely as these stones are uncommon (< 5% of all kidney stones), and the patient has no signs of dehydration or gout.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnesium ammonium phosphate kidney stones, also known as struvite stones, are caused by infection with urease-producing organisms (e.g., Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus) within the urinary tract. They account for ∼ 15% of kidney stones and tend to fill the renal pelvis. This patient does not have a history of UTI nor is the imaging consistent with a struvite stone.

C) INCORRECT:

Cystine stones result from an autosomal recessive defect in transporter proteins of the proximal convoluted tubules, which impairs cystine reabsorption. This condition is known as cystinuria. The increased urinary cystine results in stone formation. Although a cystine stone is possible, it is very unlikely since it makes up < 1% of all kidney stones. Additionally, urinalysis would have shown elevated levels of amino acids lysine, ornithine, and/or arginine as they share the same transporter protein with cystine and their reabsorption is typically also affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Hereditary xanthinuria is a very rare autosomal recessive condition that leads to the accumulation and deposition of xanthine in the kidneys. More than half of affected patients develop nephrolithiasis before the age of 10 years. The remainder usually present with nephrolithiasis later in adolescence. Xanthine deposition is an unlikely cause for kidney stones, particularly for a patient in his 30s without a history of nephrolithiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Calcium kidney stones, most commonly composed of calcium oxalate, account for 80% of kidney stones. Hyperoxaluria resulting from excessive dietary intake of vegetables containing oxalate (e.g. beets, beans, spinach), excessive vitamin C, or bile acid malabsorption (e.g. Crohn disease) can cause these stones to form. This patient's consumption of high dose vitamin C (given his multivitamin intake) has most likely contributed to the development of a kidney stone.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.

Key learning point: Calcium oxalate is the most common composition of kidney stones, accounting for approximately 80% of cases.
questions.hint: This is the most common type of kidney stone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of worsening lower abdominal pain and nausea for the past 2 hours. He reports that the pain projects into his right groin and testis. One month ago, he woke up during the night because of similar pain in his right side. The pain became excruciating after 30 minutes and resolved spontaneously after 6 hours. He goes to the gym at least 6 days each week and started a new diet 3 months ago in an effort to build up muscle mass. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right side and reduced frequency of bowel sounds; guarding and rebound tenderness are absent. There is no swelling or erythema of the groin and scrotum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralytic ileus results in reduced bowel sounds, abdominal pain, and nausea. However, in paralytic ileus, abdominal pain is caused by intestinal distention; it typically occurs days after the onset of paralytic ileus and is present diffusely in the abdomen; a paralytic ileus alone does not explain the hyperacute onset of lower abdominal pain, tenderness on the right side of the abdomen, or the radiation of pain to the groin and testis seen here. This patient has a mild paralytic ileus but his symptoms are caused by a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion can manifest with groin pain, nausea, and lower abdominal pain. Vigorous physical activity is a risk factor and patients might also report a similar episode in the past that resolved spontaneously (intermittent testicular torsion). However, in testicular torsion, the pain starts in the testicle and radiates to the abdomen, whereas the opposite is seen here. Moreover, other features of testicular torsion, including testicular swelling, testicular tenderness, and abnormal position of the testicle, would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection of the epididymis, most commonly caused by bacterial urinary tract infections or sexually transmitted infections, may manifest with unilateral scrotal pain, flank pain, and a low-grade fever. However, in epididymitis, the pain starts in the scrotum and may radiate to the ipsilateral flank, whereas the opposite is seen here. Furthermore, other features of infection of the epididymis, including scrotal swelling and scrotal erythema, are not seen in this patient. Finally, nausea, abdominal tenderness, and reduced bowel sounds are not typical features of epididymitis.

D) CORRECT:

Kidney stones classically manifest with nausea and sudden episodes of severe, unilateral abdominal and flank pain (renal colic) due to distention of the renal capsule and/or the ureter proximal to the obstruction. The pain radiates to the ipsilateral lower abdomen, groin, testicles (or labia majora in women), and perineum (typically T10–S4 dermatomes) as the stone migrates from the renal pelvis through the ureter. Occasionally, on abdominal palpation, there is also mild tenderness in the vicinity of the stone. The pain of renal colic increases steadily, typically reaches maximum intensity within 1–2 hours, and then plateaus until the stone leaves the ureter (usually after another few hours) or is removed. Although intermittent pain exacerbations (lasting several minutes) can occur as a result of ureteral peristalsis, the term renal “colic” is considered a misnomer because the pain does not cease completely in between exacerbations as it often does with intestinal colic. The passage of the stone into the bladder characteristically results in rapid relief from pain. The two episodes of renal colic in this patient resulted from two different ureteral stones; recurrence of urolithiasis is common.

Depending on the location of the stone, urolithiasis may resemble conditions such as appendicitis or testicular torsion. The reduced bowel sounds on auscultation of the abdomen most likely indicate that the patient has a mild adynamic ileus, which is a reflexive response to severe pain.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial, coronal, and sagittal planes) of a 54-year-old patient with a history of renal calculi

An obstructive calculus (green arrowhead) is present in the proximal left ureter. Pelvicaliectasis and ureteral dilatation (green overlay) are seen to the level of the calculus. There is a small amount of asymmetric fat and fascial stranding around the left kidney and proximal ureter as a result of edema.

Additional findings include a small hypodense right adrenal mass (yellow overlay), small hepatic hypodensities (example indicated by white arrowhead), a lumbosacral perineural (Tarlov) cyst (red overlay), and atherosclerotic calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

An incarcerated groin hernia (e.g., femoral hernia, inguinal hernia) can result in dragging groin pain, and weightlifting is a risk factor for hernia development. An incarcerated hernia can also cause nausea and abdominal pain as a result of mechanical bowel obstruction. However, a patient with mechanical bowel obstruction would have hyperactive rather than hypoactive bowel sounds, and there is no groin swelling in this patient to suggest a hernia. Moreover, the presence of tenderness on the right side of the abdomen, the previous episode of similar pain one month ago, and the pattern of change in pain intensity during the previous episode are not consistent with an incarcerated hernia.
questions.hint: A diet rich in animal protein (e.g., to build up muscle mass), which increases calcium and uric acid excretion and decreases the level of urinary citrate, is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the office because of sudden, right-sided flank pain, nausea, and vomiting that started 4 hours ago. The pain radiates down to her groin. She has never had any similar episodes in the past. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen without guarding. McBurney sign is negative. There is tenderness to percussion at the right costovertebral angle. Urine studies show:


Blood
3+


Protein
1+


RBCs
5–10/hpf


WBCs
2/hpf


Casts
none


Nitrites
negative


Leukocyte esterase
negative


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the bladder and kidneys
X-ray of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder
Noncontrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the bladder and kidneys alone can be used as an initial imaging test for patients in whom radiation exposure should be minimized (e.g., in children, pregnancy). Moreover, because ultrasonography of the kidney has a high sensitivity to detect hydronephrosis, it is also used in the emergency department in patients with a known history of stone disease and recurrent flank pain in order to minimize cumulative radiation exposure. In most adult patients with the first instance of flank pain from suspected stone disease, such as this woman, radiation exposure from imaging is not a significant concern and a different imaging modality is preferred. Ultrasonography alone has a relatively low sensitivity for stone detection, especially for small stones and distal ureteric stones.

B) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (KUB) alone is not used for the initial diagnosis of nephrolithiasis because it has poor sensitivity in detecting very small stones and stones composed of cystine or uric acid (radiolucent on x-ray). Also, bowel contents can obscure the visualization of a stone by a KUB x-ray. This imaging modality is more commonly used to monitor patients with nephrolithiasis for stone passage rather than for initial diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Metabolic evaluation including serum calcium, phosphorus, uric acid, bicarbonate, PTH, and a twenty-four-hour urine profile, is indicated in patients with recurrent nephrolithiasis and high-risk, first-time stone formers (e.g., patients with a solitary or a transplanted kidney) to identify possible risk factors for stone formation (e.g., decreased urine pH, hypocitraturia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricemia, hyperparathyroidism). However, this is the patient's first episode of nephrolithiasis, and she is not considered high-risk; therefore, a metabolic evaluation is not indicated.

D) CORRECT:

A noncontrast CT scan (NCCT) of the abdomen and pelvis is the gold standard diagnostic exam for most adult patients with the first instance of sudden flank pain as it has a sensitivity and specificity of > 95% for the diagnosis of renal and ureteric stones. NCCT demonstrates the calculus location, size, density, and degree of obstruction (hydronephrosis); nearly all stones are radiopaque on NCCT. Renal ultrasonography (USG) with an x-ray of the kidney, ureter, and bladder (KUB) is not as sensitive as NCCT, especially for small stones. However, since most small stones are passed spontaneously, the combination of renal USG and KUB x-ray is a reasonable and cheaper initial imaging protocol to detect large stones (i.e., ones that might require removal) when NCCT is not available. In patients in whom radiation exposure should be minimized (e.g., children, pregnant patients), renal USG alone is the imaging modality of choice. In recent years, reduced-radiation NCCT has become available and can be safely used in children. NCCT also has the advantage of being able to detect atypical causes of flank pain such as diverticulitis and appendicitis.

A contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen and pelvis is only indicated when the initial NCCT cannot clearly differentiate between phleboliths and a stone. A CECT is also indicated when delineation of the urinary tract is required, as is the case with complex stones or patients with atypical anatomy (e.g., horseshoe kidney, transplanted kidney).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial, coronal, and sagittal planes) of a 54-year-old patient with a history of renal calculi

An obstructive calculus (green arrowhead) is present in the proximal left ureter. Pelvicaliectasis and ureteral dilatation (green overlay) are seen to the level of the calculus. There is a small amount of asymmetric fat and fascial stranding around the left kidney and proximal ureter as a result of edema.

Additional findings include a small hypodense right adrenal mass (yellow overlay), small hepatic hypodensities (example indicated by white arrowhead), a lumbosacral perineural (Tarlov) cyst (red overlay), and atherosclerotic calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is obtained in patients with nephrolithiasis and clinical or laboratory signs of a urinary tract infection, such as fever, dysuria, pyuria, positive leukocyte esterase, and positive nitrites, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: Sudden flank pain that radiates to the groin, hematuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness are highly suggestive of nephrolithiasis. Nausea and vomiting are reflexive responses to severe pain.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of kidney stones presents for follow-up 5 days after a visit to the emergency department for right-sided flank pain and nausea. She was visiting her son in Arizona at the time, and a CT scan of her abdomen showed a small, solitary kidney stone in the right ureter. This is her third episode of kidney stones. Today, she feels well and reports no hematuria, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. On physical examination, she has no flank tenderness on palpation and no peripheral edema. The results of a basic metabolic panel, including serum sodium, potassium, calcium, creatinine, and phosphorus, are within normal limits. What is the best next step in evaluating this patient’s recurrent nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with recurrent kidney stones, the goal of evaluation is to identify the type of stone to inform a plan for preventing further recurrence. The evaluation should include a focused history, metabolic panel, radiographic imaging with CT, stone analysis (if a stone is available), and 24-hour urine studies. The next step is to conduct 24-hour urine studies to assess urine volume, pH, and excretion of calcium, uric acid, citrate, oxalate, sodium, potassium, Stone retrieval for analysis would have been ideal but is not currently possible in this patient as she has already passed the stone.

Key learning point: Evaluation of patients with recurrent kidney stones should include a focused history, metabolic panel, CT, 24-hour urine studies, and stone analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring parathyroid hormone levels is not indicated at this point because the patient’s calcium and creatinine levels are within normal limits. If the 24-hour urine collection reveals hypercalciuria, then measurement of the parathyroid hormone level would be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of 25-hydroxyvitamin D is not needed but would be appropriate if there were hypercalciuria, hypophosphatemia, or hyperparathyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Although radiographic imaging can be used to assess stone burden in patients with recurrent stones, CT is preferred over radiographs and has already been completed in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring the uric acid level would be helpful if this patient had a history of gout or other conditions that predisposed her to an acidic urine (e.g., chronic diarrhea, diabetes mellitus, or metabolic syndrome) as uric acid is more likely to precipitate in urine with a low pH. However, her history is more consistent with calcium oxalate stones, and a 24-hour urine study would be more helpful.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with hypertension presents 4 months after her most recent episode of symptomatic nephrolithiasis. She has passed three kidney stones in the past 5 years. No stones have been analyzed. The results of a basic metabolic panel, including serum sodium, potassium, calcium, creatinine, uric acid, and phosphorus, are within normal limits. Results of a 24-hour urine study shows:


pH
6.7 (N= 0.8–6.2)


Sodium
101 mEq/24 hr (N= 50–150)


Calcium

321 mg/24 hr (N= <200)


Oxalate
28 mg/24 hr (N= 20–40)


Citrate
570 mg/24 hr (N= >550)


Noncontrast CT with 2-mm-slice width shows several 1- to 3-mm nonobstructing calyceal stones in both kidneys. No other abnormalities are noted. Which one of the following management approaches is most likely to prevent further recurrences of this patient’s nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Potassium citrate is appropriate for patients with a low urine citrate level. It is also useful in conjunction with thiazide diuretics to offset hypokalemia that may develop from thiazides. Treatment with potassium citrate could predispose to the development of calcium phosphate stones in patients with an elevated urine phosphate level and alkaline urine. This is a concern in this patient, whose urine pH is above normal; potassium citrate is likely to raise the pH further and increase the risk of calcium phosphate precipitation.

B) INCORRECT:

A high-sodium diet can increase urine calcium and limit the efficacy of thiazide diuretics. Dietary sodium should therefore be limited to <2300 mg/day (100 mmol/day). This patient already follows a low-sodium diet (as evidenced by her 24-hour urine sodium level), so further restriction is unlikely to have a significant effect.

C) CORRECT:

Calcium stones are the most common types of kidney stones and can result from hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, hypocitraturia, or low urine volume. In a patient with a normal serum calcium level, hypercalciuria, and recurrent kidney stones of unknown composition, hypercalciuria is the most likely cause of the stones. Thiazide diuretics, such as chlorthalidone, can reduce urine calcium levels and have long been the mainstay of pharmacologic therapy for treatment of kidney stones secondary to idiopathic hypercalciuria.

Key learning point: In a patient with recurrent kidney stones of unknown composition, hypercalciuria, and no other urine abnormalities, the risk for recurrent nephrolithiasis can be reduced by initiating treatment with a thiazide diuretic.

D) INCORRECT:

Diets high in oxalate-rich foods (such as spinach [but not kale], rhubarb, buckwheat, and almonds) can result in hyperoxaluria. A low-oxalate diet is unlikely to benefit this patient, who does not have a high urine oxalate level.

E) INCORRECT:

A low-calcium diet increases urine oxalate, thus paradoxically increasing the risk of stone formation, and is not advisable. Instead, age-appropriate dietary calcium intake is recommended.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right-sided back pain, nausea, and dark urine. He reports alternating episodes of decreased urine output followed by a temporary increase in urine output for the past 2 days. In the past year, he has had two urinary tract infections. He has Crohn disease and underwent a small bowel resection 5 years ago. He currently takes mesalamine and a multivitamin. Examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 70 RBC/hpf and envelope-shaped crystals. Which of the following factors has most likely contributed most to this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A parathyroid gland adenoma could cause pathologically increased secretion of parathyroid hormone and lead to clinical hyperparathyroidism. This often results in hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria, which contribute to calcium stone formation. These stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate stones, but the risk of calcium phosphate stones is also increased. This patient does not have any other symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., weakness, constipation, irritability), making hyperparathyroidism less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective tubular amino acid reabsorption is the underlying cause of cystinuria, an autosomal recessive disorder that increases the risk of cystine stones. However, in cystinuria, stone formation would typically manifest in childhood and hexagon-shaped crystals would be seen on urinalysis, rather than the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Furthermore, a positive sodium nitroprusside test would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) increase the risk of struvite stones. This patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections; however, they are unlikely to be the cause of his stones. Struvite stones would appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lid appearance) on urinalysis, not the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Struvite stones are often quite large and fill the entire renal pelvis and calyces on imaging studies.

D) CORRECT:

Malabsorption of fatty acids due to deficiency in bile acids is common in patients with Crohn disease (and/or short bowel syndrome) and likely explains this patient's nephrolithiasis. In the intestinal lumen, undigested fatty acids chelate calcium, which would normally bind oxalate and lead to its excretion in the feces. Patients with Crohn disease often have pathologically increased luminal oxalate and increased oxalate absorption. After entering the serum, oxalate is excreted in the urine (hyperoxaluria), where it binds calcium and forms calcium oxalate stones.

Episodes of increased urination followed by oliguria are caused by temporary ureteral obstruction by stones. If a ureter is blocked, urine cannot pass through. When the obstruction is relieved, copious urine flows into the bladder.

E) INCORRECT:

High urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of calcium phosphate stones, which appear as wedge-shaped prisms on urinalysis. An alkaline environment increases the concentration of dibasic phosphate (HPO42-) in the urine, which is prone to bind to dicationic calcium (Ca2+) to form calcium phosphate stones. A high urine pH is also a risk factor for the formation of struvite stones, which appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lids) on urinalysis. In contrast, a low urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of oxalate stones.
questions.hint: Envelope-shaped crystals on urinalysis indicate calcium oxalate crystals.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from her nursing home because of increasing confusion and lethargy for 12 hours. She has a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis for which she underwent percutaneous nephrolithotomy repeatedly. She has chronic, intractable urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation of the lower abdomen. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to person. Urine studies show:


pH

8.5 (N = 5.0 – 8.0)


Protein
2+


WBC
35/hpf


Bacteria
moderate


Nitrites
positive


Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with a UTI, alkaline urine (pH > 8), and an indwelling urinary catheter are most likely infected with Proteus mirabilis. P. mirabilis converts urea in the urine into ammonia, which has an alkalizing effect and can cause magnesium ammonium phosphate stones (i.e., struvite kidney stones), which typically require interventional stone removal. The incidence of P. mirabilis increases with the duration of catheterization; it is rare in short-term catheterization but has been found in ∼ 40% of chronically catheterized patients. In this case, empiric antibiotic treatment with parenteral ceftriaxone or ciprofloxacin, urine culture and sensitivity testing, replacement of the urinary catheter (due to risk of colonization and biofilm formation), and (if confirmed) stone removal are the most appropriate next steps in management.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor recurrent nephrolithiasis. Furthermore, because enterococci are unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in case of enterococcal UTI.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI, especially because of its ability to form biofilms that are resistant to antibiotic therapy. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor does it commonly lead to recurrent nephrolithiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common cause of UTI in young, sexually active women. It is rare in older and/or catheterized patients. Although S. saprophyticus produces urease and thereby alkalinizes urine, it is unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite. Therefore, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in cases of staphylococcal UTI.

E) INCORRECT:

Enterobacter cloacae can cause UTI, particularly in women. It is rare in catheterized patients, does not produce an alkaline urine pH, and is not associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis.
