questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory studies are highly suggestive of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The organism most likely responsible produces urease, which can convert urea into ammonia and lend urine a characteristic scent.

questions.text: A previously healthy 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of several hours of severe, right-sided, colicky flank pain that radiates to the groin. He drinks 2–3 energy drinks daily. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a 4-mm radiopaque mass in the right ureter. Microscopic examination of the urine shows biconcave, dumbbell-shaped crystals. Which of the following is most likely to prevent future episodes of flank pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate crystallizes in an acidic environment and is soluble in an alkaline environment. In a patient with calcium oxalate stones, alkalinization of urine would prevent recurrent stone formation. This can be achieved with a diet rich in fruits and vegetables or potassium citrate. Urinary acidification is recommended for prevention of calcium phosphate or struvite stones.

B) CORRECT:

Inadequate hydration causes supersaturation of solutes in urine, which increases the risk of stone formation. Fluid intake of ≥ 2.5 L/day reduces the risk of recurrent nephrolithiasis because it decreases the urinary solute concentration and increases the frequency of urination. Adequate hydration prevents recurrence of all types of urinary stones. This patient should also be advised against excessive consumption of energy drinks, which often contain oxalate and contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

Calcium oxalate stones can also appear as bipyramidal envelopes on urinalysis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, which is then excreted in urine. High doses of supplemental vitamin C cause oxalate supersaturation in urine, which promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Starting this patient on supplemental vitamin C is therefore not the best course of action.

D) INCORRECT:

Restricting normal dietary calcium intake (approx. 1000 mg/day) enhances the intestinal absorption of oxalate. This increases urinary oxalate excretion and the risk of recurrent calcium oxalate stones. In addition, prolonged low dietary calcium can decrease bone mineral density and cause osteoporosis. However, supplemental calcium intake (above the normal daily requirements) should be restricted in patients with calcium stones.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the association between caffeinated beverages and formation of renal stones is not entirely clear, increased (not decreased) caffeine consumption (either coffee or tea) decreases the recurrence rate of nephrolithiasis, most likely by improving urinary flow and decreasing urinary supersaturation. Coffee and tea also have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that potentially reduce the risk of stone formation.
questions.hint: The radiopaque mass in the area of the ureter and biconcave dumbbells on urinalysis confirm the diagnosis of calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the office because of an 8-hour history of severe right flank pain. He is nauseous and has vomited twice since the onset of his symptoms. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, metoprolol, and a vitamin C supplement. There is tenderness to palpation at the right costovertebral angle. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, and nontender prostate. Urinalysis shows 17 RBCs/hpf. A nonenhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows a 7-mm stone in the distal right ureter without associated hydronephrosis. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and oral ibuprofen therapy are started. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate can be used in the treatment of uncomplicated upper urinary tract infections (UTIs), which can occur as a complication of urolithiasis. However, patients with upper UTIs typically present with fever, chills, dysuria, and pyuria. This patient has no signs or symptoms of a concomitant UTI that would warrant antibiotic treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Bethanechol, a parasympathomimetic agent, causes contraction of the detrusor muscle and is used in the treatment of urinary retention and neurogenic bladder. Bethanechol does not have any effect on ureter smooth muscle and would therefore not facilitate stone passage.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide can be considered for prophylaxis in patients with recurrent calcium-containing stones and idiopathic hypercalciuria. Patients taking vitamin C are at an increased risk of calcium-containing stones because vitamin C is converted to oxalate, excreted in the urine, and can bind with calcium to form calcium oxalate stones. Although this patient likely has a calcium oxalate stone, which is the most common type of stone, he presents with an uncomplicated ureteral stone for the first time and should receive treatment rather than prophylaxis for recurring stones.

D) INCORRECT:

Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) can be used in medical expulsive therapy to facilitate the passage of uncomplicated stones. However, diltiazem is a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that exerts its effects primarily on cardiac muscles, and it is most commonly used as an antihypertensive. Diltiazem has not been shown to be useful in the management of ureteral stones.

E) CORRECT:

Tamsulosin, an α1-blocker, decreases ureteral smooth muscle contractions, which can facilitate the passage of ureteral stones and reduce the use of pain medications. α1-blockers and dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are the mainstays of medical expulsion therapy, which is the suggested treatment for ureteral stones ≤ 10 mm that are uncomplicated (e.g., in patients who are hemodynamically stable, have no signs of infection, and have no hydronephrosis). Uncomplicated stones < 5 mm typically pass spontaneously and do not require treatment. A urology consultation is necessary for patients with complicated stones (e.g., concomitant high-grade obstruction, urosepsis, impending acute kidney injury, intractable pain, vomiting) for discussion of noninvasive and surgical interventions.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral contrast; coronal plane)

A nonobstructive hyperdense calculus (red circle) is present in the left renal pelvis. Atherosclerotic calcifications (red arrowheads) of the abdominal aorta (red overlay) are also seen. Metal streak artifacts (white arrows) between the aorta and inferior vena cava (blue overlay) are caused by an internal spinal fixator.

K and dashed lines: kidney; Li: liver, Lu: lung; PM: psoas major muscle; S: stomach with oral contrast; UB: urinary bladder
questions.hint: This patient has a small distal ureteral stone and would benefit from an agent that facilitates stone passage.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe right flank pain for 2 hours. The pain is colicky in nature and she describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. She has had 2 episodes of vomiting. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F). The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant. Bowel sounds are reduced. Her leukocyte count is 7400/mm3. A low-dose CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a round 14-mm stone in the distal right ureter. Urine dipstick is mildly positive for blood. Microscopic examination of the urine shows RBCs and no WBCs. Intravenous 0.9% saline infusion is begun, and intravenous ketorolac is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Interventional management with stone removal is the most appropriate step in management for patients with large urinary stones (> 10 mm). For patients with ureteral stones, ureterorenoscopy (URS) and extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) are the preferred treatment modalities. Generally, URS is preferred over ESWL for the removal of stones in the middle and distal ureter. After removal, the composition of the stone is analyzed so that specific guidance on lifestyle and/or diet can be provided. The most important measure to prevent urinary stones in any patient is adequate fluid intake to decrease the risk of crystallization.

B) INCORRECT:

Prior to the invention of endoscopy, ureterolithotomy used to be the standard treatment for complex ureteral stones that did not pass spontaneously or in patients who developed sepsis. Today, however, surgical stone removal, including robotic-assisted or traditional laparoscopic removal is only considered in rare cases in which interventional methods (i.e., shock wave lithotripsy, endoscopic stone removal) have failed, or are likely to fail in the future (e.g., because of large, complex stones). This patient has a simple round stone and no clinical signs of sepsis (e.g., fever, hypotension, tachypnea).

C) INCORRECT:

A trial of conservative management consisting of medical expulsive therapy (e.g., tamsulosin) and analgesia under observation is indicated for patients with small (≤ 10 mm), uncomplicated stones. Because larger stones are unlikely to pass spontaneously, another step in management is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Ureteral stenting is recommended in patients with ureteral stones who develop complications such as (infected) hydronephrosis or sepsis. This patient does not have fever, leukocytosis, or an elevated WBCs on urine microscopy, which would suggest a urinary tract infection. Furthermore, ureteral stenting is not routinely recommended prior to any ureteral intervention.
questions.hint: Severe unilateral colicky flank pain, vomiting, costovertebral angle tenderness, and hematuria suggest urolithiasis. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirms an uncomplicated large stone in the distal right ureter.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with recurrent right-sided flank pain for the past 3 weeks. He has a 6-year history of gout. Urinalysis shows no red blood cell casts, normal RBC count, and a pH of 5.0 (see reports).

Plain abdominal radiographs: No stones
Intravenous pyelogram: Filling defect in the right renal pelvis
Renal ultrasound: Hyperechoic lesion with acoustic shadowing in the right renal pelvis

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate stones are typically radiopaque due to their calcium content, making them visible on plain abdominal radiographs. The absence of stones on the radiograph contradicts this diagnosis. Additionally, the acidic urine pH and history of gout suggest a non-calcium stone composition.

B) CORRECT:

Uric acid stones form in acidic urine, typically when the pH is below 5.5, promoting uric acid crystal precipitation. The urine pH of 5.0 in this patient supports uric acid stone formation. These stones are radiolucent on plain abdominal radiographs due to their lack of calcium, explaining their absence on this imaging. However, they appear as filling defects on intravenous pyelograms and as hyperechoic lesions with acoustic shadowing on renal ultrasound. The patient's history of gout, associated with hyperuricemia, further increases the likelihood of uric acid stone formation.

Key learning point: Uric acid stones are radiolucent and can cause non-opaque filling defects on IVP, and they produce acoustic shadowing on ultrasound due to their density.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

C) INCORRECT:

Struvite stones form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacterial infections, which raise the pH. The urine pH of 5.0 is acidic, not supporting struvite stone formation. Additionally, there is no history of recurrent urinary tract infections, which are typically associated with struvite stones.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystine stones are associated with cystinuria, a hereditary condition presenting with recurrent stones from a young age. They are moderately radiopaque, often visible on radiographs. The patient's age and history of gout, along with the acidic urine, do not align with cystine stone characteristics.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a year-long history of involuntary urine loss when sneezing or coughing. She has not sought medical care for this issue. Over the past week, she has experienced intermittent severe right flank pain radiating to her groin, accompanied by microscopic hematuria. She denies any chronic urinary urgency. On physical examination, she appears comfortable, with stable vital signs and no flank tenderness. Mild relaxation of the pelvic floor muscles is noted, without significant pelvic organ prolapse. Urinalysis is unremarkable except for red blood cells. No imaging or conservative measures have been performed yet.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation or management?

choices.text: Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient presents with severe right flank pain radiating to the groin and microscopic hematuria, suggesting nephrolithiasis. Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the preferred imaging modality for suspected ureteral stones due to its high sensitivity and specificity. It provides detailed information on stone size, location, and density, guiding management decisions. While stress urinary incontinence is present, it is a chronic condition that can be addressed separately with conservative measures.

Key learning point: For stress urinary incontinence, pelvic floor muscle training (Kegel exercises) is a recommended management strategy. In cases of suspected renal colic, a CT of the abdomen without contrast is the preferred diagnostic investigation.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy evaluates the lower urinary tract for lesions or bladder pathologies. The patient's symptoms suggest an upper tract issue, such as nephrolithiasis, which is better assessed with non-contrast CT rather than cystoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is useful for detecting hydronephrosis and gross renal abnormalities but lacks sensitivity for small or non-obstructing ureteral stones. In this patient with flank pain and hematuria, non-contrast CT is more appropriate for detecting ureteral calculi.

D) INCORRECT:

Mid-urethral sling surgery is a treatment for stress urinary incontinence, typically considered after conservative measures fail. The patient has not yet undergone conservative management, and her flank pain and hematuria suggest a need to evaluate for nephrolithiasis first.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with recurrent calcium stones has persistent hypercalciuria despite hydration and dietary changes. Which measure best reduces recurrent stone formation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol reduces uric acid production and is used for uric acid stones or hyperuricosuria. This patient's recurrent stones are due to hypercalciuria, not elevated uric acid, making thiazide diuretics more appropriate for reducing urinary calcium.

B) INCORRECT:

While increased fluid intake dilutes urinary solutes and reduces stone risk, this patient has persistent hypercalciuria despite hydration. The underlying issue of excessive urinary calcium excretion requires interventions that modify renal calcium handling, not just further dilution.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathyroidectomy is indicated for primary hyperparathyroidism with elevated serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels. This patient lacks evidence of hyperparathyroidism, and the focus is on managing hypercalciuria, not surgical intervention.

D) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics decrease urinary calcium excretion by enhancing calcium reabsorption in the distal tubules. This reduces the supersaturation of calcium salts in the urine, directly addressing hypercalciuria, a key factor in calcium stone formation. Thiazides are effective for patients with recurrent calcium stones who remain hypercalciuric despite hydration and dietary changes. Monitoring and dose adjustments are necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalances.

Key learning point: Thiazide diuretics are effective in reducing urinary calcium excretion and are the most useful therapy for preventing stone formation in patients with hypercalciuria.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man has severe right flank pain radiating to the groin with microscopic hematuria. What imaging test is most appropriate?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
Noncontrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is useful for detecting hydronephrosis or larger renal calculi, especially in patients where radiation is a concern. However, it has lower sensitivity for small ureteral stones and lacks the resolution to reliably detect and characterize stone size, location, and density.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) historically assessed the urinary system but has lower sensitivity for small stones compared to modern imaging. It requires iodinated contrast, posing risks like hypersensitivity and nephropathy, and involves a time-consuming protocol, making it less suitable for acute management.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) provides excellent soft tissue contrast but is less sensitive for detecting calcifications compared to CT. While useful for soft tissue pathologies, MRI is not ideal for diagnosing urinary stones, where noncontrast CT offers superior sensitivity and rapid acquisition.

D) CORRECT:

Noncontrast computed tomography (CT) is the preferred imaging modality for suspected renal colic due to its high-resolution visualization of urinary calculi, including small or radiolucent stones. It accurately delineates stone size, location, and density, essential for management and predicting spontaneous passage. The absence of contrast prevents calcification obscuration, allowing precise detection. This rapid and widely available technique confirms stone presence, assesses complications like hydronephrosis, and evaluates alternative causes of flank pain.

Key learning point: A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for diagnosing kidney stones in patients with renal colic.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation who presents to the emergency department with severe right-sided back pain for the past hour. The pain is colicky and radiates to her right groin. She also reports nausea and dysuria. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has no personal or family history of serious illness, and she does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. On examination, there is right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine studies show:


Protein, urine
Negative


RBC casts, urine
Negative


RBC, urine
5–7/hpf


WBC casts, urine
Negative


WBC, urine
1–2/hpf


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lower urinary tract infection (e.g., cystitis) is very common in pregnant patients since the enlarging uterus increases urinary stasis and progesterone diminishes the effectiveness of bladder mobility. Infections generally present with low-grade or no fever, dysuria, and suprapubic tenderness. Urinalysis shows hematuria, positive leukocyte esterase, and pyuria. In this patient, the absence of true pyuria (> 10 WBC/hpf) and the presence of colicky flank pain are inconsistent with the common presentation of a lower urinary tract infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion is a surgical emergency seen most often in nonpregnant and first-trimester women as the gravid uterus limits the mobility of the ovaries in women further along in pregnancy. Affected patients often describe acute progressive, unilateral, lower quadrant pain after exercise or other physical activity. This patient is already in the 30th week of pregnancy. Moreover, ovarian torsion could not explain the microscopic hematuria or costovertebral tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis is a significant cause of maternal and fetal morbidity. The typical presentation consists of high fevers (> 39.0° C), chills, and constant unilateral flank pain with dysuria as well as urinary frequency and urgency. Urinalysis almost always exhibits hematuria and pyuria. Although this patient has flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and hematuria, she does not have fever and/or significant pyuria, which makes pyelonephritis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Appendicitis is the most common nonobstetrical indication for abdominal surgery in pregnant women. However, the classic presentation consists of new-onset abdominal pain that begins diffusely in the periumbilical area and subsequently migrates to the right lower quadrant. Nausea, vomiting, fever, and reduced appetite are also often present. Although appendicitis may also manifest in a nonclassic fashion, e.g. with the kind of pain described here, it is not the most likely explanation for this patient's condition. Additionally, it would not explain her dysuria and hematuria.

E) CORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis typically manifests with unilateral, colicky flank pain that may radiate to the groin with associated costovertebral angle tenderness and is usually associated with microscopic hematuria and dysuria. To confirm the diagnosis, imaging is required. The gold standard would be a nonenhanced abdominopelvic CT scan to calculate size, site, and density of the stone and detect possible hydronephrosis on the affected side. However, since this patient is pregnant, the modality of choice would be ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and the bladder, which can also rule out other gynecological differential diagnoses.

Key learning point: Nephrolithiasis in pregnancy presents with unilateral, colicky flank pain radiating to the groin, costovertebral angle tenderness, dysuria, and microscopic hematuria; ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic imaging modality during pregnancy.
questions.hint: This condition is more common among dehydrated individuals and those who use loop diuretics and antacids.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 66-year-old woman with hypertension who presents 4 months after her most recent episode of symptomatic nephrolithiasis. She has passed three kidney stones over the past 5 years, but none have been analyzed. A basic metabolic panel, including serum sodium, potassium, calcium, creatinine, uric acid, and phosphorus, is within normal limits. A 24-hour urine study shows the following:


pH, urine
6.7 (5.0–8.5)


Sodium (Na), urine, 24-h specimen
101 mmol/24 h (40.0–220.0)


Urine calcium (Ca), unrestricted diet, 24-h specimen

8.0 mmol/24 h (2.5–7.5)


Oxalate
28 mg/24 h (20–40)


Citrate
570 mg/24 h (>550)


Noncontrast CT with 2-mm-slice width shows several 1- to 3-mm nonobstructing calyceal stones in both kidneys. No other abnormalities are seen. Which one of the following management approaches is most likely to prevent further recurrences of her nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Calcium stones are the most common types of kidney stones and can result from hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, hypocitraturia, or low urine volume. In a patient with a normal serum calcium level, hypercalciuria, and recurrent kidney stones of unknown composition, hypercalciuria is the most likely cause of the stones. Thiazide diuretics, such as chlorthalidone, can reduce urine calcium levels and have long been the mainstay of pharmacologic therapy for treatment of kidney stones secondary to idiopathic hypercalciuria.

Key learning point: In a patient with recurrent kidney stones of unknown composition, hypercalciuria, and no other urine abnormalities, the risk for recurrent nephrolithiasis can be reduced by initiating treatment with a thiazide diuretic.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium citrate is appropriate for patients with a low urine citrate level. It is also useful in conjunction with thiazide diuretics to offset hypokalemia that may develop from thiazides. Treatment with potassium citrate could predispose to the development of calcium phosphate stones in patients with an elevated urine phosphate level and alkaline urine. This is a concern in this patient, whose urine pH is above normal; potassium citrate is likely to raise the pH further and increase the risk of calcium phosphate precipitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Diets high in oxalate-rich foods (such as spinach [but not kale], rhubarb, buckwheat, and almonds) can result in hyperoxaluria. A low-oxalate diet is unlikely to benefit this patient, who does not have a high urine oxalate level.

D) INCORRECT:

A high-sodium diet can increase urine calcium and limit the efficacy of thiazide diuretics. Dietary sodium should therefore be limited to < 2300 mg/day (100 mmol/day). This patient already follows a low-sodium diet (as evidenced by her 24-hour urine sodium level), so further restriction is unlikely to have a significant effect.

E) INCORRECT:

A low-calcium diet increases urine oxalate, thus paradoxically increasing the risk of stone formation, and is not advisable. Instead, age-appropriate dietary calcium intake is recommended.

questions.text: You are seeing a 62-year-old man in the emergency department with right-sided back pain, nausea, and dark urine. He describes alternating episodes of decreased and increased urine output over the past 2 days. Over the past year, he has had two urinary tract infections. His medical history includes Crohn disease and a small bowel resection 5 years ago. His current medications are mesalamine and a multivitamin. On examination, he has right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals 70 RBC/hpf and envelope-shaped crystals. Which one of the following factors has most likely contributed most to his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective tubular amino acid reabsorption is the underlying cause of cystinuria, an autosomal recessive disorder that increases the risk of cystine stones. However, in cystinuria, stone formation would typically manifest in childhood and hexagon-shaped crystals would be seen on urinalysis, rather than the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Furthermore, a positive sodium nitroprusside test would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

High urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of calcium phosphate stones, which appear as wedge-shaped prisms on urinalysis. An alkaline environment increases the concentration of dibasic phosphate (HPO42-) in the urine, which is prone to bind to dicationic calcium (Ca2+) to form calcium phosphate stones. A high urine pH is also a risk factor for the formation of struvite stones, which appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lids) on urinalysis. In contrast, a low urine pH is a risk factor for the precipitation of oxalate stones.

C) INCORRECT:

A parathyroid gland adenoma could cause pathologically increased secretion of parathyroid hormone and lead to clinical hyperparathyroidism. This often results in hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria, which contribute to calcium stone formation. These stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate stones, but the risk of calcium phosphate stones is also increased. This patient does not have any other symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., weakness, constipation, irritability), making hyperparathyroidism less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis) increase the risk of struvite stones. This patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections; however, they are unlikely to be the cause of his stones. Struvite stones would appear as rectangular prisms (coffin-lid appearance) on urinalysis, not the envelope-shaped crystals seen here. Struvite stones are often quite large and fill the entire renal pelvis and calyces on imaging studies.

E) CORRECT:

Malabsorption of fatty acids due to deficiency in bile acids is common in patients with Crohn disease (and/or short bowel syndrome) and likely explains this patient's nephrolithiasis. In the intestinal lumen, undigested fatty acids chelate calcium, which would normally bind oxalate and lead to its excretion in the feces. Patients with Crohn disease often have pathologically increased luminal oxalate and increased oxalate absorption. After entering the serum, oxalate is excreted in the urine (hyperoxaluria), where it binds calcium and forms calcium oxalate stones.

Episodes of increased urination followed by oliguria are caused by temporary ureteral obstruction by stones. If a ureter is blocked, urine cannot pass through. When the obstruction is relieved, copious urine flows into the bladder.

Key learning point: Crohn disease and small bowel resection can cause fat malabsorption, leading to increased intestinal oxalate absorption and a higher risk of calcium oxalate kidney stones.
questions.hint: Envelope-shaped crystals on urinalysis indicate calcium oxalate crystals.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from her nursing home because of increasing confusion and lethargy for the past 12 hours. She has a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis and has undergone multiple percutaneous nephrolithotomies. She has chronic, intractable urinary incontinence and an indwelling urinary catheter. Her temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg. On examination, there is mild tenderness to palpation of the lower abdomen. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to person. Urine studies show:


pH, urine

8.5 (5.0 – 8.5)


Protein
2+


WBC, urine
35/hpf


Nitrites, urine
positive


Bacteria, urine
moderate


Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with a UTI, alkaline urine (pH > 8), and an indwelling urinary catheter are most likely infected with Proteus mirabilis. P. mirabilis converts urea in the urine into ammonia, which has an alkalizing effect and can cause magnesium ammonium phosphate stones (i.e., struvite kidney stones), which typically require interventional stone removal. The incidence of P. mirabilis increases with the duration of catheterization; it is rare in short-term catheterization but has been found in ∼ 40% of chronically catheterized patients. In this case, empiric antibiotic treatment with parenteral ceftriaxone or ciprofloxacin, urine culture and sensitivity testing, replacement of the urinary catheter (due to risk of colonization and biofilm formation), and (if confirmed) stone removal are the most appropriate next steps in management.

Key learning point: Proteus mirabilis is a urease-producing organism that commonly causes catheter-associated urinary tract infections with alkaline urine and is associated with struvite kidney stones.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterobacter cloacae can cause UTI, particularly in women. It is rare in catheterized patients, does not produce an alkaline urine pH, and is not associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI, especially because of its ability to form biofilms that are resistant to antibiotic therapy. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor does it commonly lead to recurrent nephrolithiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of catheter-associated UTI. However, it neither causes alkaline urine nor recurrent nephrolithiasis. Furthermore, because enterococci are unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in case of enterococcal UTI.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a common cause of UTI in young, sexually active women. It is rare in older and/or catheterized patients. Although S. saprophyticus produces urease and thereby alkalinizes urine, it is unable to reduce nitrate to nitrite. Therefore, the urinary nitrite test would be negative in cases of staphylococcal UTI.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory studies are highly suggestive of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The organism most likely responsible produces urease, which can convert urea into ammonia and lend urine a characteristic scent.

questions.text: A previously healthy 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department with several hours of severe, right-sided, colicky flank pain radiating to the groin. He reports drinking 2–3 energy drinks daily. An abdominal x-ray reveals a 4-mm radiopaque mass in the right ureter. Microscopic examination of his urine shows biconcave, dumbbell-shaped crystals. Which one of the following is most likely to prevent future episodes of flank pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the association between caffeinated beverages and formation of renal stones is not entirely clear, increased (not decreased) caffeine consumption (either coffee or tea) decreases the recurrence rate of nephrolithiasis, most likely by improving urinary flow and decreasing urinary supersaturation. Coffee and tea also have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that potentially reduce the risk of stone formation.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, which is then excreted in urine. High doses of supplemental vitamin C cause oxalate supersaturation in urine, which promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Starting this patient on supplemental vitamin C is therefore not the best course of action.

C) CORRECT:

Inadequate hydration causes supersaturation of solutes in urine, which increases the risk of stone formation. Fluid intake of ≥ 2.5 L/day reduces the risk of recurrent nephrolithiasis because it decreases the urinary solute concentration and increases the frequency of urination. Adequate hydration prevents recurrence of all types of urinary stones. This patient should also be advised against excessive consumption of energy drinks, which often contain oxalate and contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

Key learning point: Adequate hydration is the most effective way to prevent recurrence of kidney stones.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate crystallizes in an acidic environment and is soluble in an alkaline environment. In a patient with calcium oxalate stones, alkalinization of urine would prevent recurrent stone formation. This can be achieved with a diet rich in fruits and vegetables or potassium citrate. Urinary acidification may help prevent calcium phosphate or struvite stones.

E) INCORRECT:

Restricting normal dietary calcium intake (approx. 1000 mg/day) enhances the intestinal absorption of oxalate. This increases urinary oxalate excretion and the risk of recurrent calcium oxalate stones. In addition, prolonged low dietary calcium can decrease bone mineral density and cause osteoporosis. However, supplemental calcium intake (above the normal daily requirements) should be restricted in patients with calcium stones.
questions.hint: The radiopaque mass in the area of the ureter and biconcave dumbbells or bipyramidal envelopes on urinalysis confirm the diagnosis of calcium oxalate stones, which are the most common type of kidney stones.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with left flank pain for 6 hours. He describes the pain as severe and constant, with radiation to the groin. He has had two episodes of vomiting and appears restless. Vital signs are BP, 125/70 mm Hg; P, 105; R, not provided; T, 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood, positive leukocyte esterase, and positive nitrites. Ultrasound of the left kidney and CT are shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide analgesia and admit for observation
Prescribe tamsulosin and schedule urology follow-up
Start IV antibiotics and consult urology urgently
Discharge with oral ciprofloxacin and primary care follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While appropriate analgesia is important in renal colic, this approach is inadequate for this patient with infected obstructing nephrolithiasis. This patient's fever and moderate hydronephrosis indicate the need for more intensive treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is appropriate for medical expulsive therapy in uncomplicated nephrolithiasis, but outpatient follow-up is inappropriate when infection is present with obstruction.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of fever, positive urinalysis findings (leukocyte esterase and nitrites), and obstructing stone with hydronephrosis indicates infected nephrolithiasis. This represents a urological emergency requiring immediate antibiotic therapy and urgent urology consultation for definitive management such as ureteral stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy to relieve obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management with oral antibiotics is inappropriate for infected obstructing nephrolithiasis. This patient's fever and moderate hydronephrosis indicate the need for hospitalization and potentially urgent intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

ESWL is an option for ureteral stones in uncomplicated cases. However, ESWL is not the treatment of choice for infected kidney stones, which necessitate immediate relief of obstruction through ureteral stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy rather than stone fragmentation procedures.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with severe right flank pain radiating to his groin and hematuria. He reports taking 4 grams of vitamin C daily for immune support. A non-contrast CT scan reveals a 4-mm stone in the right ureter. Urinalysis shows numerous red blood cells and envelope-shaped crystals. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Decreased urinary pH promoting urate precipitation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypocitraturia is a significant risk factor for this type of stone formation because citrate normally binds to urinary calcium, preventing it from precipitating with oxalate. However, vitamin C intake does not cause hypocitraturia. This condition is more commonly associated with metabolic acidosis, such as in distal renal tubular acidosis or chronic diarrhea.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for nephrolithiasis, and the urinalysis finding of envelope-shaped crystals specifically indicates calcium oxalate stones. High doses of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) are metabolized to oxalate, leading to hyperoxaluria. The increased concentration of oxalate in the urine supersaturates the tubular fluid, where it binds with calcium to form insoluble calcium oxalate crystals. These crystals can aggregate to form stones, causing obstruction and the typical symptoms of renal colic. Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone, and identifiable risk factors include high dietary oxalate intake, vitamin C supplementation, and malabsorption syndromes like Crohn disease.

C) INCORRECT:

High doses of vitamin C can acidify the urine, and an acidic environment does favor the formation of uric acid stones. However, the urinalysis in this patient shows envelope-shaped crystals, not the rhomboid or needle-shaped crystals seen with uric acid stones. Thus, this is not the primary mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypercalciuria is a common cause of calcium-containing kidney stones. However, vitamin C supplementation does not directly increase the intestinal absorption of calcium. While this patient has a calcium-based stone, the direct metabolic consequence of his high vitamin C intake is an overproduction of another substance, not an increase in calcium absorption.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased renal ammonia production raises urinary pH, creating an alkaline environment. This promotes the formation of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones, which are associated with urease-producing bacterial infections (e.g., Proteus mirabilis). The patient's history and the finding of envelope-shaped crystals are inconsistent with this mechanism.
questions.hint: The urinalysis finding of envelope-shaped crystals is typical of the most common type of nephrolithiasis. Consider how this patient's high-dose supplement use could lead to the formation of these specific crystals.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe, colicky right flank pain radiating to his groin, accompanied by nausea. He is afebrile. Physical examination reveals right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis is significant for gross hematuria. A non-contrast CT confirms an obstructing kidney stone on the right side. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely associated with the composition of this patient's stone?

choices.text: Elevated serum parathyroid hormone and hypercalcemia
Elevated serum uric acid and urine pH of 5.0
Normal serum calcium and urine pH of 6.0
Positive urine nitrite and urine pH of 8.0

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperparathyroidism is a known cause of hypercalcemia and subsequent hypercalciuria, which increases the risk for calcium-containing stones (both oxalate and phosphate). However, this represents a specific, relatively uncommon cause of nephrolithiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

These findings are associated with uric acid stones. Uric acid is less soluble in acidic environments, and these stones typically form when the urine pH is persistently below 5.5. While hyperuricemia is a risk factor, many patients have normal serum uric acid levels. Uric acid stones are less common than other urinary stones.

C) INCORRECT:

The finding of hexagonal crystals on urine microscopy is pathognomonic for cystine stones. These stones are caused by cystinuria, a rare autosomal recessive disorder of amino acid transport. Given the rarity of this condition compared to other types of urinary stones, this is an unlikely finding in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The most common type of kidney stones (approximately 75%) are calcium oxalate stones. The most frequent metabolic abnormality leading to these stones is idiopathic hypercalciuria, where urinary calcium excretion is elevated despite normal serum calcium levels. Formation of calcium oxalate crystals is favored in a urine pH of 5.5 to 6.5. A pH of 6.0 is well within this range. Other major risk factors include low urine volume, hypocitraturia (citrate is an inhibitor of stone formation), and hyperoxaluria. While hypercalcemic states can cause calcium stones, normocalcemia is the far more common finding.

E) INCORRECT:

These findings are characteristic of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones, also known as infection stones. They form in the presence of urease-producing bacteria like Proteus or Klebsiella, which hydrolyze urea to ammonia, creating a persistently alkaline urine (pH > 7.2). This patient is afebrile and lacks typical signs of a urinary tract infection, making this a less likely etiology.
questions.hint: This patient likely has the most common type of urinary stone, and its metabolic profile provides important diagnostic clues.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of terminal ileum resection for inflammatory bowel disease presents with acute-onset, severe left flank pain radiating to the groin and gross hematuria. A non-contrast abdominal CT confirms a 5-mm obstructive calculus at the ureterovesical junction. Urinalysis shows numerous calcium oxalate crystals. Which of the following pathophysiologic mechanisms is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Impaired renal tubular reabsorption of amino acids
Bicarbonate loss leading to acidic urine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired renal tubular reabsorption of amino acids causes cystinuria, a genetic disorder affecting the transport of dibasic amino acids (Cystine, Ornithine, Lysine, Arginine). Poor reabsorption of cystine leads to high urinary concentrations and the formation of hexagonal cystine crystals and stones. This patient's urinalysis showed calcium oxalate crystals, not cystine crystals.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypocitraturia is a significant risk factor for calcium stone formation because citrate normally chelates urinary calcium, inhibiting crystallization. While chronic diarrhea from IBD can cause metabolic acidosis, which in turn leads to hypocitraturia, the primary mechanism directly linking terminal ileal disease to calcium oxalate stones is enteric hyperoxaluria.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic diarrhea, which can occur in IBD, leads to gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss and a resulting metabolic acidosis. The kidneys compensate by excreting more acid, leading to acidic urine pH.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history of terminal ileum resection due to inflammatory bowel disease causes fat malabsorption. Normally, dietary calcium binds to dietary oxalate in the gut, forming an insoluble precipitate that is excreted. In fat malabsorption, unabsorbed fatty acids bind to intestinal calcium, a process known as saponification. This leaves oxalate unbound and soluble, leading to its increased absorption in the colon. The subsequent rise in urinary oxalate excretion (enteric hyperoxaluria) promotes the supersaturation of calcium oxalate in the urine, leading to crystal formation and stones. This is the classic mechanism for calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis in patients with Crohn disease, short bowel syndrome, or after bariatric surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary infection with urease-producing bacteria leads to the formation of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones. Urease-producing organisms, such as Proteus mirabilis, hydrolyze urea to ammonia, which alkalinizes the urine (pH > 7.2) and promotes struvite precipitation. The patient has calcium oxalate crystals, and there are no signs of a urinary tract infection.
questions.hint: Fat malabsorption, a common consequence of terminal ileum resection, alters the normal binding of dietary calcium in the gut.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P0 at 22 weeks' gestation, comes to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of acute-onset, severe right flank pain. The pain is sharp, intermittent, and radiates to her right groin. She reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. She denies fever or chills but notes her urine appears slightly pink. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination reveals a patient in distress, with marked right costovertebral angle tenderness. The abdomen is gravid and non-tender. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A kidney, ureter, and bladder radiograph involves the use of ionizing radiation and has low sensitivity for detecting kidney stones. It can only visualize radiopaque stones (e.g., calcium-based), and its utility is often limited in pregnancy due to the overlying gravid uterus and fetal skeleton obscuring the view of the ureters. It provides significantly less diagnostic information than alternative imaging methods.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography is an older imaging technique that has been largely replaced by CT for evaluating nephrolithiasis. It requires the administration of iodinated contrast and involves a substantial dose of ionizing radiation from multiple X-rays. Due to the radiation exposure and potential risks of contrast to the fetus, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast is the gold standard for diagnosing nephrolithiasis in non-pregnant adults due to its high sensitivity and specificity. However, it is avoided as the initial test in pregnant patients because it exposes the fetus to significant ionizing radiation, which is associated with risks of teratogenicity and childhood malignancy. Low-dose protocols exist but are typically reserved for cases where ultrasound is non-diagnostic and there is high clinical suspicion.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance urography (MRU) does not use ionizing radiation and can effectively visualize the urinary tract and hydronephrosis. However, it is less readily available in the emergency setting, more time-consuming, and more expensive than ultrasound. It is considered a second-line imaging modality for suspected nephrolithiasis in pregnancy, typically used when ultrasound findings are equivocal.

E) CORRECT:

In a pregnant patient, the initial diagnostic imaging modality of choice is renal and bladder ultrasonography because it avoids ionizing radiation, which poses a risk to the fetus. Ultrasound is effective for identifying hydronephrosis, which is a key secondary sign of an obstructing stone. While it may not always visualize the stone directly, especially if it is in the mid-ureter, the presence of hydronephrosis in this clinical context is highly suggestive of the diagnosis and sufficient to guide initial management. Doppler ultrasonography can further increase diagnostic accuracy by assessing for ureteral jets.
questions.hint: This patient’s presentation of acute, severe, colicky flank pain radiating to the groin, with costovertebral angle tenderness and hematuria, is consistent with nephrolithiasis. The choice of imaging must prioritize fetal safety.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of severe, colicky left flank pain radiating to his groin. He reports nausea and gross hematuria. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 155/92 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals significant left costovertebral angle tenderness. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis identifies a 6-mm calculus at the left ureterovesical junction with mild hydroureter. In addition to hydration and analgesia, which of the following medications is most likely to facilitate the passage of this patient's calculus?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used for the long-term prevention of recurrent calcium oxalate stones. It acts by increasing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which reduces urinary calcium excretion. However, it has no role in the acute setting to facilitate the passage of an existing ureteral stone.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium citrate is used in the long-term management and prevention of certain types of kidney stones, specifically uric acid and calcium oxalate stones. It works by alkalinizing the urine and increasing urinary citrate levels. It does not have a role in the acute management of an obstructing stone by promoting its passage through the ureter.

C) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, causes smooth muscle relaxation and has been studied for medical expulsive therapy. Although it may be used in certain circumstances, current guidelines favor an alternative medication. Nifedipine is considered a second-line agent for this indication.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has an uncomplicated, obstructing 6-mm ureteral stone, for which medical expulsive therapy is indicated. Tamsulosin is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist that is first-line for this purpose. Alpha-1 receptors are densely located in the smooth muscle of the distal ureter and bladder neck. By blocking these receptors, tamsulosin induces smooth muscle relaxation, which decreases ureteral spasm and intraureteral pressure. This facilitates the passage of stones, particularly those between 5 and 10 mm located in the distal ureter. It is typically prescribed for up to four weeks and is given in conjunction with adequate hydration and analgesia.
questions.hint: The distal ureter contains a high concentration of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors. A medication that blocks these receptors will relax the smooth muscle and aid in stone expulsion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe, colicky left flank pain radiating to his groin. He is nauseated and has vomited once. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg, heart rate is 112/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination reveals significant left costovertebral angle tenderness. A non-contrast CT scan confirms a 5-mm stone at the left ureterovesical junction. An initial dose of intravenous ketorolac has provided minimal relief of his 10/10 pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next analgesic medication to administer?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The next step in pain management for this patient with severe pain from nephrolithiasis that is refractory to first-line NSAID therapy is a parenteral opioid. Intravenous administration is preferred for its rapid onset and titratability, especially in a patient with nausea and vomiting that may limit oral absorption. Hydromorphone is an excellent choice as it is a potent opioid agonist with a quick onset of action (5-10 minutes). Compared to other opioids, it has a lower propensity to cause histamine release, resulting in less hypotension and pruritus. Importantly, it does not have active metabolites that accumulate in renal impairment, which is a potential concern in patients with obstructive uropathy from a kidney stone.

B) INCORRECT:

Meperidine is generally avoided for pain management. Its metabolite, normeperidine, is a neurotoxin that can accumulate, especially in renal impairment, leading to an increased risk of seizures. The intramuscular route also provides erratic absorption and is more painful than intravenous administration. Safer and more effective alternatives are readily available and preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral medications are inappropriate for managing this patient's severe, 10/10 acute pain, which requires rapid relief. The onset of action for oral oxycodone is too slow. Additionally, this patient's nausea and vomiting make the oral route unreliable due to the risk of emesis and uncertain gastrointestinal absorption.

D) INCORRECT:

A transdermal fentanyl patch is indicated for the management of stable, chronic pain in opioid-tolerant patients, not for acute pain. It has a very slow onset of action, taking 12-24 hours to achieve a therapeutic effect, which is completely inadequate for providing rapid relief in an emergency setting like this.
questions.hint: This patient has severe, acute pain from nephrolithiasis that is refractory to first-line NSAID therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of severe, colicky left flank pain that radiates to his groin. He has had two episodes of non-bloody emesis and reports hematuria. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 158/92 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination is remarkable for left costovertebral angle tenderness. A non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a 12-mm calculus in the proximal left ureter with associated moderate hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous fluids and ketorolac with observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pain control with NSAIDs (like ketorolac) and hydration are the cornerstones of initial emergency management for renal colic. However, this addresses symptoms, not the underlying obstruction. Given the large size of the stone (12 mm) and associated hydronephrosis, spontaneous passage is very unlikely. Therefore, observation alone after initial stabilization is inappropriate, and a urologic intervention is required.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a symptomatic, obstructing 12-mm stone in the proximal ureter that is unlikely to pass spontaneously. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) is a first-line, non-invasive treatment for stones of this size and location. This procedure uses externally generated, high-energy acoustic shock waves to fragment the calculus into smaller pieces that can then be passed in the urine. Given that the patient is afebrile and does not show signs of urosepsis, an elective procedure like SWL is appropriate. Other indications for intervention include severe pain, renal failure, or persistent obstruction. Ureteroscopy is an alternative first-line option, but SWL is less invasive.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous nephrolithotomy is a surgical procedure reserved for large or complex stones, typically those >20 mm located within the renal pelvis or calyces (e.g., staghorn calculi). It involves creating a tract from the skin on the back directly into the kidney to remove the stone. This invasive procedure is not indicated for a 12-mm stone located in the ureter.

D) INCORRECT:

Medical expulsive therapy with an alpha-blocker like tamsulosin is appropriate for facilitating the passage of small, uncomplicated ureteral stones, typically those <10 mm. However, its efficacy decreases significantly with larger stones. Given that this stone is 12 mm and is causing moderate hydronephrosis and severe pain, a trial of passage has a low likelihood of success, and a more definitive intervention is indicated.
questions.hint: The management of ureteral stones is guided by the stone's size and location.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of severe, colicky left flank pain radiating to his groin. He rates the pain as 10/10 and reports nausea. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 155/92 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. Examination shows left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows large blood and 2–5 WBCs/hpf. A noncontrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 7-mm calculus at the left ureterovesical junction with moderate hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Discharge with instructions for hydration and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs only
Admit for percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement
Schedule for extracorporeal shock wave lithotriopsy
Initiate tamsulosin and provide oral analgesics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ureteroscopy is a definitive surgical treatment for ureteral stones but is not the appropriate initial step in this stable patient. Urgent intervention is reserved for patients with signs of urosepsis (e.g., fever, leukocytosis), acute kidney injury, anuria, or intractable pain and vomiting that cannot be controlled with medication. This patient does not currently meet these criteria, which makes a trial of conservative management appropriate first.

B) INCORRECT:

While hydration and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are essential components of managing nephrolithiasis, this approach is incomplete for a 7-mm stone. The likelihood of spontaneous passage for a stone of this size is significantly increased with a different management approach.

C) INCORRECT:

A percutaneous nephrostomy tube is an invasive procedure used to decompress the upper urinary tract. Its primary indication is in cases of an obstructed and infected kidney (pyonephrosis) to provide drainage and control sepsis, or in cases of severe acute kidney injury from the obstruction. This patient is afebrile and has no signs of a complicated infection, making this procedure unnecessarily invasive as an initial step.

D) INCORRECT:

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a noninvasive option for treating some kidney stones. However, it is generally less effective for stones located in the distal ureter, such as at the ureterovesical junction. Furthermore, ESWL is an elective procedure that would be considered after a different management approach has been unsuccessful.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has an uncomplicated but symptomatic ureteral stone. For stones between 5 and 10 mm, medical expulsive therapy (MET) is recommended to facilitate spontaneous passage. Tamsulosin, an alpha-1 antagonist, relaxes the smooth muscle of the distal ureter, reducing spasm and increasing the likelihood of stone expulsion. Adequate pain control, typically with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, is also a critical component of initial management. Because the patient is afebrile, stable, and has no signs of severe infection or acute kidney injury, a trial of passage with MET and analgesia is the most appropriate initial step. Patients are instructed to strain their urine to catch the stone for analysis.
questions.hint: This patient has an obstructing ureteral stone without signs of infection or renal failure.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe, colicky left-sided flank pain that radiates to his groin. He has had two episodes of nonbloody emesis. He is unable to find a comfortable position and is constantly shifting on the gurney. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a distressed-appearing man. His abdomen is soft and nontender. There is marked tenderness to percussion over the left costovertebral angle. Urinalysis shows 50–100 RBCs/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis can cause flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. However, it is an infection of the kidney and would typically be accompanied by fever, chills, and systemic signs of illness. The urinalysis would primarily show pyuria (WBCs), leukocyte esterase, and nitrites, rather than isolated hematuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion presents with acute, severe groin or testicular pain and can cause nausea and vomiting. However, the pain originates in the scrotum, not the flank. Physical examination would show a tender, high-riding testicle and an absent cremasteric reflex; these findings are not present in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis typically manifests with the acute onset of severe, colicky flank pain that radiates to the groin as the stone migrates down the ureter. The pain is caused by ureteral spasm and distension of the renal capsule from obstruction. Associated symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and a characteristic restlessness in which the patient cannot find a comfortable position. Physical examination shows costovertebral angle tenderness. The diagnosis is strongly supported by the urinalysis finding of microscopic hematuria, which results from the stone abrading the urothelial lining. The initial diagnostic imaging of choice is a noncontrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

D) INCORRECT:

Appendicitis can cause abdominal pain and vomiting. However, the pain classically begins in the periumbilical region and migrates to the right lower quadrant. This patient's pain is on the left side and localized to the flank. The key physical finding would be right lower quadrant tenderness, not costovertebral angle tenderness.

E) INCORRECT:

A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm can cause severe, acute flank or back pain. However, this is a catastrophic event typically seen in older adults with atherosclerotic risk factors. It classically presents with hypotension, syncope, and a pulsatile abdominal mass, none of which are present in this patient.
questions.hint: Severe, colicky flank pain, hematuria, and restlessness are a classic triad for a specific urologic emergency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents for follow-up one month after an episode of severe left flank pain radiating to the groin. He passed a stone, which was retrieved and analyzed, confirming a composition of calcium oxalate. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He reports that he has already increased his daily water consumption. He is eager to make lifestyle changes to avoid another painful episode. In addition to maintaining high fluid intake, which of the following recommendations is most likely to reduce his risk of future stone formation?

choices.text: Increase intake of leafy green vegetables

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose vitamin C (ascorbic acid) supplementation should be avoided in patients with a history of calcium oxalate stones. Ascorbic acid is metabolized to oxalate in the body. Supplementation can significantly increase urinary oxalate excretion, thereby raising the risk of stone formation. This recommendation would likely be harmful.

B) CORRECT:

Decreasing dietary sodium is a crucial recommendation for preventing recurrent calcium oxalate stones. High dietary sodium intake promotes urinary calcium excretion (hypercalciuria) because sodium and calcium share a common transport mechanism in the renal proximal tubule. When sodium intake is high, its reabsorption is reduced, which in turn decreases calcium reabsorption, leading to higher calcium levels in the urine. This increased urinary calcium concentration raises the saturation of calcium oxalate, promoting crystal formation. Therefore, a low-sodium diet is a primary intervention to reduce the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation.

C) INCORRECT:

This recommendation could increase the risk of stone formation. Many leafy green vegetables, such as spinach, rhubarb, and beet greens, are very high in oxalate. Increasing the consumption of high-oxalate foods can lead to increased urinary oxalate excretion (hyperoxaluria), which is a major risk factor for the development of calcium oxalate stones.

D) INCORRECT:

While it may seem intuitive to restrict calcium for calcium-based stones, this action is counterproductive. Dietary calcium binds to oxalate in the gut, forming an insoluble complex that is excreted in the feces. Restricting dietary calcium allows for increased free oxalate absorption from the intestine, leading to higher urinary oxalate levels (hyperoxaluria) and an increased risk of stone formation. A normal dietary calcium intake is recommended.
questions.hint: Increased urinary excretion of certain electrolytes can induce an increase in others, thereby promoting stone formation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of left flank pain and dysuria. She has had 2 episodes of urinary tract infection over the past 2 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and pulse is 82/min. An ultrasound of the kidneys shows left-sided hydronephrosis and echogenic foci with acoustic shadowing. A photomicrograph of the urine is shown. The crystals observed are most likely composed of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uric acid precipitation results in rhomboid-shaped, radiolucent stone formation. Uric acid stones account for about 10% of kidney stones. Risk factors for uric acid crystal formation include low urine volume, high uric acid excretion, acidic urine, and hyperuricemia (e.g., gout, tumor lysis syndrome).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).

B) INCORRECT:

Cystine precipitation results in the formation of radiopaque, hexagonal crystals. Cystine stones account for only 1% of kidney stones and are typically found in individuals with an autosomal recessive defect of a proximal convoluted tubule transporter responsible for reabsorption of dibasic amino acids (e.g., cystine, ornithine, arginine, and lysine). The resulting cystinuria predisposes to stone formation because cystine has low solubility in urine. Diagnosis is made by direct visualization of the stones or with a positive urine sodium cyanide nitroprusside test.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cystine crystals from a canine urine sample (1000x magnification)

A clump of multiple, clear, hexagon-shaped crystals is visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of cystine crystals.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate precipitation results in radiopaque crystals that have an envelope or dumbbell shape on urine microscopy. Calcium oxalate stones account for 70–80% of kidney stones. Important risk factors for these stones include decreased urine volume, increased urine calcium or oxalate excretion, and decreased urine citrate excretion.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium phosphate precipitation results in radiopaque crystals that appear as wedge-shaped prisms on urine microscopy. Calcium phosphate stones account for 15% of kidney stones and are frequently present in combination with struvite stones or calcium oxalate stones. Risk factors for calcium phosphate stones include increased urine calcium and phosphate excretion, low urine citrate excretion, and increased urine pH; Hypercalcemia, however, is not typically observed.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph showing crystals with the appearance of wedge-shaped prisms (can also be described as blunt-ended needles), some bound together forming a rosette.

E) CORRECT:

Struvite stones are comprised of magnesium ammonium phosphate and account for 5–10% of kidney stones. Precipitation of this compound occurs in the setting of alkaline urine, which is commonly attributed to increased ammonia production by urease-producing bacterial species such as Proteus or Klebsiella. Elevated urine pH reduces phosphate solubility and increases the risk of struvite stone formation.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view)

A large branching structure is seen within the renal pelvis and several enlarged calyces (green overlay). The appearance is typical of a struvite staghorn calculus. The term “staghorn calculus” is used when at least two calyces are involved, giving rise to the appearance of a stag's antlers.

Struvite calculi are caused by urease-producing bacteria. Calcium carbonate precipitates with struvite to form large calculi that are radiographically visible and conform to the renal collecting system.

Severe lumbar rotatory scoliosis is also seen on the radiograph.

P: renal pelvis; VB: vertebrae
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of nephrolithiasis (left flank pain and hydronephrosis) with struvite stones (coffin lid appearance) in her urine.
